name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on combating sexual abuse and exploitation of children (2020/2702(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we as adults are responsible for the safety of children. We as politicians are responsible for legislation to protect children, and, to be honest, I don’t think we are doing enough. There are people out there who use and abuse children, and we have the obligation to protect our children from these predators. In June, I spoke at the webinar jointly hosted with the European Parliament Intergroup on Children’s Rights. Many experts and decision makers and our allies in the struggle spoke there – the Dutch Government, Europol, the United States National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC) – but most impressive was the testimony of Sarah. Sarah is a survivor. She was groomed online as a teenager and forced into sex slavery. She said to us, ‘Let my story not become a story we would hear from a friend, sister or mother’. So let’s do her justice.  I know that you all feel as strongly as I do about this, but just let me repeat some of the terrible statistics. In the last 10 years, reports by internet companies of child sexual abuse increased exponentially. From 1 million to 17 million worldwide in 10 years, and from 23 000 to 725 000 in Europe. European servers host the majority of this content. Reports of abuse increased during COVID. In the country I know best, a perpetrator posted, ‘Thank you, Corona. Now it’s so easy to find the children.’ Behind the statistics, there are real children, sometimes very small children. From the country I know best, we are seeing that, during Corona, small children around the age of seven were groomed and by March the grooming of children at that age had been growing; children of that age forced to film themselves. And they were told, ‘if you tell anybody, I will kill your dog or your hamster’. You can imagine how that is for a small child.  These predators have a business model that fuels this increase. Closed and secret groups on the internet have an entrance fee of new and unseen material. To see videos of raped children, paedophiles must rape children. That’s how the business model works. Most of the perpetrators are men, but not only men; 10% to 20% of offences are committed by women, or with the aid of women. Most of the victims are girls, but not only girls. Around 15% to 20% are boys.  Supported by Europol, police forces in our Member States are cracking down on abuse. The DarkScandals website was taken down with more than 2 000 videos and images. This website used the slogan ‘real blackmail, rape and forced videos of girls all around the world’. Police have taken down this site. The owner is now behind bars. But we need to do much more to support the police. In your resolution, this House asked us to work with industry and the big ICT companies, because detection and reporting by internet companies is necessary to save children.  Last week, I presented a regulation, an interim solution, to make sure internet companies can continue to detect, report and remove child sexual abuse material. Why am I proposing interim legislation? Because of an unintended effect of the Electronic Communications Code, and this comes into force in December this year. That would have an unintended effect: companies will no longer be allowed to pursue their voluntary efforts to detect and report child abuse online. That would pull the rug out from under our entire law enforcement effort against predators. Last year, law enforcement in Europe received 40 000 newly produced images and 100 000 newly produced videos, images that made it possible for authorities to find children and prosecute perpetrators. If we do not adopt that interim legislation, this will no longer be possible. I call on you to support this important regulation, which is a temporary solution until our long-term sector-specific legislation is in place. We are now working on this permanent legislation and will present it by next June, proposals that would make it mandatory for companies to detect and report known child sexual abuse materials to public authorities. Current EU legislation puts strong obligations on internet companies to protect copyright – but not children who are being raped. And of course we must protect children more than we protect copyright.  We also want to set up a European centre to prevent and counter child sexual abuse. In Ireland, police get 80% of their tip-offs from the US-based National Center for Missing & Exploited Children, and only 20% from parents and guardians. Just last Friday, two men were sentenced to 13 years in prison in Germany. They had had abused two girls for five years and that was thanks to a NCMEC report that saved them. It’s time for Europe to have its own centre, to build on Europol’s work, to work with companies and law-enforcement bodies, to identify victims and bring offenders to justice. I will soon launch a study as a first step in setting up our own European centre against child sexual abuse. The EU directive on child sexual abuse dates from 2011. I will launch a study to assist its implementation and to see how and where we need to upgrade and update our legislation. We cannot allow paedophiles or perpetrators to win an online high-tech arms race. To keep one step ahead, Europol will set up an innovation hub and lab. We will support Member States with funding. The Commission is also working with experts and industry to find technical solutions to detect and report encrypted online child sexual abuse.  I must underline that this is, of course, important to do without prohibiting or weakening encryption, and in full respect of privacy. I must say, I do not accept that we have to choose between protecting children or privacy. It’s absolutely possible to combine the two. But we must also work on prevention. Very often children are abused by someone they know and trust. We will create a prevention network of practitioners and researchers to share expertise to stop perpetrators from acting. We also need to encourage children, to tell them, ‘it’s not your fault’.  It’s not okay what these adults are doing. We need to empower children to speak out. And I want Europe to take global leadership, because abuse doesn’t stop at national or European borders. We will work together with governments, tech companies and civil society organisations worldwide.  I need your help to pass this legislation. I need your help to protect children. A child has no power, and children that are abused least of all. But we do have power, so let’s use that power to protect children. (Applause)

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Thank you Chairman. And thank you also to the Commissioner for her introduction. It's to be quiet. I became a father for the first time this year and that feeling is nothing compared to it. The love, the responsibility, the urge to protect your child is very special.  It makes me sick to my heart that there are people in this world who have fun or make money abusing children. And yet we see that abuse is increasing, and quite well, you have said that. I am also pleased that the Commission is showing this urgency here today. I miss that urgency with the Member States. It is scandalous that 23 of the 27 Member States have infringement procedures for non-implementation of the 2011 Child Abuse Directive. What the hell is the point of making arrangements here together if no one executes them?  Child pornography should be detected, reported and removed as soon as possible. Hosting companies play a crucial role in this and they have to take that responsibility, whether they don't like it or not. We have to force them to do that. And that has to be done with rules and with naming and shaming. In the Netherlands, a blacklist of hosting companies that do not cooperate will soon be published, and I would also suggest supporting such an initiative in Europe.  Finally, encryption. As you have said, encryption is extremely important for the protection of our privacy. But that is at the same time a shield behind which scumbags who are guilty of child abuse can hide. We have to find a solution to that. A child being abused is scarred for life and, as the Commissioner rightly said, we are not doing enough at the moment to prevent it. Please let today be the last day we have to say this.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Sexual offences against children are heinous crimes with serious consequences for victims. And we must combat the exchange of images online, without forgetting that child abuse is taking place in our neighbourhood – by parents, neighbors, carers, priests. Looking away and silence is not an option here as there.  As early as 2011, we adopted a directive on the protection of children from sexual abuse. However, the vast majority of Member States have failed to implement them in nine years. There is also a massive need to catch up on the prevention, support and protection of children, the harmonisation of criminal offences and penalties. Last year, the Commission had to open infringement proceedings against 23 Member States after nine years.  Child protection is an important issue. And we need to do more, including online. At the same time, however, we must not create false expectations, because there are no miracle cures with which the pictures disappear. Confidentiality of communication, privacy is important – also for our children, online. Encryption, for example, can prevent images that young people exchange with each other from being intercepted by perpetrators and shared with third parties.  That is why it is quite clear that we need to better protect our children online and offline. Legislation must be implemented, prevention agencies must be given more resources, law enforcement agencies must be staffed, financially and technically adequately equipped to better protect our children and their spaces offline and online.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, what’s in a number, dear colleagues? If I told you that the number of reports of child sexual abuse has increased to nearly 70 million in 2019, would you believe it? Or if I told you that, according to the Council of Europe, one out of five children falls victim to sexual violence. Would you believe it? What if I told you that Europe is the biggest hub for child pornography, that can’t be true, right? The list of these numbers goes on and on. Sixty per cent of worldwide child sexual abuse content is circulating in Europe. Isn’t that staggering? Let it be clear. Sexual abuse of children is not just one of the 99 problems. it is ‘the’ problem that all European decision makers have to face, and the fight against it must be our priority. Therefore, I would like to thank you, Commissioner Johansson, for the bold and concrete steps forward in the fight against child sexual abuse. This is a strong, balanced and comprehensive strategy. But this alone is not enough. We all know that, we all have to play a role in this fight. I am fully convinced that a dedicated EU centre will be a major added value in the fight against these terrible crimes. Commissioner Johansson, I fully support your strategy. You can count on me, on us, on Renew Europe and on the Intergroup on Children’s Rights to implement it. If we don’t do it, who will do it? So European leadership please, you can count on us.

(The President cut off the speaker)

name: Saskia Bricmont
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, dear Commissioner Johansson, ladies and gentlemen, one in five children is said to be a victim of sexual violence, and in almost 80% of cases the child knows his abuser. As a result, he is often the victim of people he trusts. Tackling sexual abuse is a top priority and we must act together. However, my speech is particularly addressed to the 23 Member States which do not apply the 2011 directive, and the absence of Council representatives today asks me: how many cases of abuse could have been avoided in all these years and how many lives will it take before the Member States actually implement the legislation? There is a blind spot in actions at the moment and that is prevention: educating and educating children and their families about this type of violence, the risks and threats associated with online presence; Putting in place genuine prevention and support programmes for perpetrators; identify and accompany victims. Measures that are already provided for by European law and yet not implemented. How effective will a new strategy be if Member States do not make the necessary efforts? Public spending should be used to strengthen our child protection, police, justice, under-equipped and understaffed services. Completing the difficult tasks assigned to them requires a fundamental overhaul of the public resources invested. In the face of these serious shortcomings, to think that technological solutions will overcome years of chronic underinvestment in the aforementioned services is a smokescreen. Our efforts must focus on the women and men on the ground who protect children, investigate, arrest and prosecute paedophiles. We want action, means and not just good intentions.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, it is distressing to take part in a debate on paedophilia and child sexual abuse the day after seeing how this European Parliament condemned Poland for trying to pass a law against paedophilia. You have been exposing for years that sex is a banal thing, hypersexualizing society, considering that sex is not part of that inviolable dignity of the human being. Look, stop talking, this is a serious problem that affects hundreds of thousands of children in Europe and has developed with the complicit silence of authorities and the media.  There are the cases of Telford or Rotherham, who were shamefully silenced by the media because pimps and abusers were of Pakistani origin; or in my country, Spain, in the Balearic Islands, where we have a case of dozens of girls prostituted in social care centres that left-wing governments are rejecting and in which they are paralyzing judicial and administrative investigation. Nor did the European Commission say anything about this case of prostituted girls in the Balearic Islands when I asked, on Vox's behalf, in January. Less talk: more law and order; harsher penalties; full compliance. We are into it by European civilization.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your initiative. We all agree here that sexual abuse against children must be firmly combated and we understand that your priority is the fight against online child crime. However, I would not want this serious subject to be used to remove the personal protection of all our fellow citizens. Let me tell you that child exploitation did not start with the internet. The Internet is sometimes only a visible part of sprawling networks of child and human exploitation using children to make a profit. Pedocriminality, sex tourism, child prostitution, domestic abuse did not begin with the internet and they cross centuries and continents. Worse, these child criminal trials were sometimes allowed, remember this writer praised for his novel about his sexual relations with a 14-year-old girl, Gabriel Matzneff. Finally, Commissioner, trafficking also starts with the abandonment of some children, I mean exiled children, Roma children, who have knowingly left the field of child protection. We can no longer accept backroom discussions, all children deserve the protection of Europe. And I think when you protect a child, you win a citizen.

name: Ewa Kopacz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Cooperation, education and assistance to victims should be among the fundamental pillars of the effective fight against child sexual exploitation and violence. The time of the pandemic clearly showed that at least part of our children's lives had moved to the internet. It's not just a matter of remote learning, it's about keeping in touch remotely, not just with your peers. We should therefore equip children and young people with the knowledge to identify the threat so that they can protect themselves and their privacy online and beyond. For this, educational programmes are needed, including age-appropriate, reliable sex education. These actions should go hand in hand with a wide-ranging campaign aimed at parents and people working with children and young people on a daily basis. I believe that the fight against sexual violence and sexual exploitation of children must be based on a comprehensive strategy that is effective both in the real world and online. All Member States should commit to such multifaceted action. The cost and consequences of an ineffective fight against sexual violence are not only a lost childhood, but also often the entire future adult life of our children. Commissioner, thank you for your proposal. As the European Parliament's coordinator for the rights of the child, I declare my full support for your actions.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you have said this: in recent years, the number of allegations of child sexual abuse has increased dramatically. The numbers are spooky: nearly 17 million allegations of sexual abuse were filed in 2019 alone, and more than 70 million images and child pornography videos were intercepted. Behind these images, there's a crime. A real abuse that truncates the lives of victims and leaves deep internal scars on them. Unfortunately, the current pandemic has helped to further aggravate the problem.  That is why I thank you, Commissioner, for your commitment to defending children's rights from the beginning of your term of office and, in particular, to focus on a serious crime that is not sufficiently talked about, and to develop a real European policy to eradicate the abuse and sexual exploitation of minors. That is why I welcome the presentation of this strategy and its proposal to include a temporary exception to certain provisions of the Privacy and Electronic Communications Directive to ensure that companies can continue to voluntarily detect child sexual abuse online.  But we must go further and be more ambitious, replacing the current Directive with a Regulation to solve transposition problems and develop clear standards for preventing and prosecuting these crimes. It also making it legal imperative to detect child sexual abuse content and its immediate communication to public authorities by major online service providers. And launching a European centre to combat and prevent child sexual abuse and supporting the role of NGOs, as we have been calling for from Parliament's Intergroup on the Rights of Children. Finally, further work is needed on prevention. We must continue to educate not only minors, but also their parents and guardians, as well as all adults who work with them, about the dangers of the virtual world, through educational and awareness-raising initiatives.  Let us act together to protect our children.

name: France Jamet (ID).
text: Mr President, Mrs Johansson, ladies and gentlemen, it is still incredible that at this time there are no reliable and real statistics on such a painful subject as the sexual abuse and exploitation of children by criminal networks. Not quantifying a problem is sometimes denying it. And we know that paedophile networks and paedophilia rely on powerful, organised mafia networks, which also take advantage of the European Union's complacency towards smugglers of all kinds, whether in the Mediterranean or Eastern Europe, or the absence of borders, which gives them full latitude for this unspeakable trafficking. We've heard your temporary proposal, but we need to track down these mobsters. We must stop them, we must apply zero tolerance against these monsters, we must be ruthless, because the place of a rapist or a child trafficker is in prison, because the sanction must give the real measure of the crime committed: the application of perpetuity. Real perpetuity.

name: Marcel Kolaja (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I fully support the protection of children. However, I am terrified that the Commission is presenting a derogation from the ePrivacy Directive – a derogation that not only approves automated filters, but also creates a blanket authorisation to use them for private communication. This is a clear threat to encryption and distraction from more serious issues, such as: first, the lack of national implementation of the Child Sexual Abuse Directive – nine whole years have passed since the adoption of this European legislation – second, the financial difficulties of many hotlines, which form the basic infrastructure of handling the analysis and reporting of child abuse material; and, third, the need to increase the capacities of the judicial system and law enforcement to make sure that they have the resources to follow up on investigations. I support the Commission’s action on tackling these serious issues, but I urge you: focus on protecting children instead of playing whack—a—mole with criminals online and violating the privacy of innocent people.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Thank you for your initiative to protect children from paedophiles. The data is alarming. It is today that Europe has become a global hotspot for the sexual exploitation of children. Almost 90% of paedophile material in the world is currently hosted on European servers, 71% of which are hosted in the Netherlands. We really need to protect children. The child is powerless, but we, as you said, have the strength to protect them. And we cannot allow paedophiles to win with us. The protection of children is absolutely paramount.  I do not agree with the previous previous err that we must choose between the protection of personal data and the protection of children. Here the choice is zero-one. Child pornography must be severely punished. Paedophiles must face the most severe punishment. But let us remember that it is in the European Union that forced marriages with children take place. Every day, children in these marriages are raped, abused and this is happening in the European Union...  (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Marion Walsmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Johannson, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. About 10 to 20% of children in Europe are sexually assaulted during their childhood. That is 10 to 20% too much.  While I welcome the European Commission's strategy to effectively combat child sexual abuse, we do not need any further studies and investigations. Time is running out. We need effective enforcement of existing legislation in the Member States.  We need concrete measures to put an end to this inhumanity online and offline. Concrete measures not only to detect cases of abuse, but to prevent them. Prevention in order to actually enable the investigating authorities to identify the perpetrators, so that data protection is not equal to the protection of perpetrators, in order to nip the spread of child pornography in the bud and to enable a child-friendly criminal procedure and appropriate victim support.

name: Jean-Lin Lacapelle (ID).
text: Mr President, your communications are of course essential when they seek to protect our children from sexual predators, but unfortunately they remain silent on two major points. The first point is the fight against products inciting paedophilia. I have as a recent example Netflix and its scandalous series entitled "Mignonnes", which features ultra-sexualized preteens and shamefully trivializes child sexuality. Second abject example: sex dolls with a child's waist and body that Amazon or Cdiscount, a subsidiary of the Casino Group, were able to freely put up for sale without raising a single word of protest, neither French nor European. The second point is the harmonisation of criminal laws within the European Union, particularly on the age of sexual consent, which leads to the very definition of rape of minors and differs completely from one European country to another. We must ensure that sexual abuse of a child in a country is punished so severely in each neighbouring country. This is an opportunity to show that Europe is not just a structure built around mercantile values. By acting on these two points, it would fight predators and protect our children.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the measure of a society is how it protects the most vulnerable. Right now, Europe is letting its children down. Interpol, Europol, the Internet Watch Foundation and many others have highlighted the shocking and vast extent of the sexual abuse of children online in Europe. Our aims are clear: that more victims need to be identified and protected that more criminals need to be brought to justice and that we will do all we can to create a world free from child sexual exploitation. To achieve this, the EU needs to lead the world on creating effective partnerships between governments, industry, law enforcement and NGOs. The EU must give the necessary political will, expertise and resources needed to end this horrific pattern of criminality once and for all, and also in how we show children on television and in the media.

text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Statistically, there is a child with experience of abuse in every school class in Germany. Most files with representations are on Dutch servers. In the last scandal alone, 500 terabytes of data were seized. Offenders and users sit all over Europe. We need a stronger European response to this horrible and, unfortunately, very dynamic business model.  The Common Centre, greater coordination of European efforts, is more necessary than ever. In addition, however, we also need a robust mandate for Europol in terms of cooperation with third parties in terms of the possibility of own investigations into the use of AI and the latest technology, in terms of the full link with SIS and the Prüm network, but also in terms of support and support for the investigators, who have to deal with this horrific data on a daily basis.  Last but not least, we need data retention, and we need e-evidence. Under no circumstances should data protection be an excuse for the protection of perpetrators.

text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much, Commissioner, for the material that you have presented. We guarantee that we will support you in all the solutions that you have put forward and planned. First of all, in order to query the possibilities of the Union and to improve the rules – sharp, clear, decisive – we will support. As adults, we must put aside our ambitions, even perhaps our freedoms, because online criminals are very fit and against children.

text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Millions of children are sexually abused every year. Every year millions of children are abused online. Every year we hear about cases of child abuse where they should feel safest, that is, in the family. Every year we hear about thousands of paedophiles who avoid criminal responsibility. And I ask you, after all, no one here has said that the experience of violence in childhood imprints a lasting stigma on the child's psyche, causes a spiral, or leads to a spiral of violence, as well as to numerous suicides. That is why I support all those who say that paedophile data should absolutely not be kept secret, it should be made public. No paedophile, regardless of origin, profession, place of residence, may use violence. I ask you, the best law – and I say this to my Polish colleagues – will not protect our children unless it is applied in the same way to all paedophiles, be it...  (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE).
text: – Mr President, after reading and listening to the Commission Communication we should not only be horrified: we should be ashamed of our inability to assume our responsibilities on this issue.  Europe has become the global distribution centre for child pornography. This is true when twenty-three of the 27 Member States – as has been recalled – have not transposed the Directive on combating sexual abuse. We need to increase the criminalization of these conducts and harmonize criminal rates.  We need to quickly establish a legal framework so that internet service providers can act more effectively on this issue. It is imperative that we support more and work closely with civil society organizations that are also in this struggle. We need new instruments of cross-border judicial cooperation and Europol's competence, which has proven to be a privileged instrument for its effectiveness in police cooperation, needs to be strengthened. We must declare war on all those who destroy the lives of thousands of children every year.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the European Union, the largest amount of child pornography circulates worldwide, according to data from the Internet Watch Foundation. This fact makes us understand the seriousness of a phenomenon that generates hateful and increasing crimes, committed both online and offline in different forms, in every segment of society.  Disabled children, migrants, girls and girls who are victims of trafficking are the vulnerable groups most at risk. The implementation of the existing legislative framework by Member States is crucial for the prevention, investigation, prosecution of crimes, as well as for the assistance and protection of victims. Cooperation between the different social actors, such as institutions, families, schools, social and health services, has a primary role in providing help and protection. If we are able to protect children we will protect the present and the future of our society.

text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Before we proceed with Commissioner Johansson's final statement, I would like to open the first round of voting today. Not to underestimate the debate, but not to delay the further course of the day.  The dossiers on which we are voting can be found on the agenda. name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on combating sexual abuse and exploitation of children (2020/2702(RSP)).

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I feel the honourable Members’ strong commitment to fighting child sexual abuse. I count on your support for the interim legislation on the table and I count on good cooperation with the implementation of the strategy. We heard from Mr Lenaers about being a parent and the strong emotions that you feel to protect your child. But I think that we all also feel, as adults, strong emotions about protecting all children and the obligation, as politicians, to take the proper measures to do so. I will work with you to protect children, both online and offline, and of course, there is also a very strong link between online and offline crimes. Ms Pelletier mentioned that because, to be able to see this content online, you have to produce new content and that is the ongoing raping and abuse of children. It is also, of course, the case that, when these materials can stay there for years, being watched again and again and again, the crime is been done again and again and again towards the victims.  I think that our upcoming European centre to prevent and counter child sexual abuse will play a key role in this area. It’s important that many of you have stressed the implementation of the directive. We already have the ongoing infringement procedures and all of you that are studying the strategy can see that there are a lot of things in the strategy that will help Member States to really implement the directive, so this will be the focus. May I also say something about the interim legislation that we have on the table. This is to avoid an unintended situation where otherwise we would make it impossible for the voluntary detection of child sex abuse materials that the companies do right now. I must say that I think that Mr Kolaja is falling into a very dangerous trap here. There is no contradiction between working on prevention, working with victims, working on the implementation of the directives, working with hotlines and also making it possible that we do not put into force an unintended effect that would stop the internet companies from doing this important detection and reporting. Hotlines play a very important role, but they only detect a very small fraction of this material because most of the material is not public. It’s in communication or more closed areas. Some of you have also mentioned trafficking and that is important. I can tell you that we are coming forward with new proposals and a new strategy to fight trafficking. That will be part of the upcoming proposals at the beginning of next year on fighting organised crime.  To conclude, I must say that there is one thing that perpetrating paedophiles fear more than anything else, and that is the light. They would like to stay and act in the dark. I think that Ms Sippel said something very wise here: being silent and looking away is simply not an option. I fully agree. Let’s turn on the light. As Ms Vautmans said, if we don’t do it, who will do it? I fully agree with that as well. We have the power. Let’s use that important power together to protect children.  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. The sexual abuse and exploitation of children is an intolerable violation of human rights. According to council of Europe estimates, one in five children in Europe is the victim of some form of sexual violence. In addition, in 2019, the EU reached the world record for hosted child pornography. And the Covid-19 crisis has aggravated an already depressing situation: in some Member States, the demand for child pornography has increased by up to 25%, and worldwide the number of reports of child sexual abuse has quadrupled. Given the often cross-border nature of these crimes, coordinated and joint action is needed at EU level to combat this phenomenon offline and online. Prevention, protection, victim assistance, investigative coordination, repression and sharing of best practices must be the priorities of a multisectoral approach, involving law enforcement authorities, researchers, child support organisations and the private sector, in particular online service providers. The strategy presented by the Commission, the result of the dialogue established with Parliament and the Intergroup on the Rights of the Child, is moving in this direction. Legislative measures and concrete actions must now follow, in order to ensure that children's rights are truly respected as laid down in Art. 24 CDFEEDS.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – Sexual violence knows no boundaries. It occurs in every country, across all parts of society. In the last ten years, online child sexual abuse increased exponentially worldwide, from 1 million reports of child sexual abuse material in 2010 to 17 million in 2019. The old warning ‘don’t talk to strangers’ has lost its power. In online chat, strangers come disguised as teenagers; they know all the right words and all the right music. The current COVID-19 pandemic has further increased the risk of sexual exploitation for children, because they are spending more time online. For children who live with their abusers, the isolation linked to the COVID-19 crisis may have dramatic consequences. Fighting child sexual exploitation is a joint effort between law enforcement, EU Member States, non-governmental organisations, international organisations and the private sector. I am very pleased that the European Commission launched in July 2020 a package of measures to better combat child sex abuse – a European strategy to fight child sexual abuse. I am convinced that such a strategy is the right way forward, as increased cooperation is needed to coordinate efforts to protect our children online. It is our obligation to protect children. Let us do what is needed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the importance of urban and green infrastructure – European Year for Greener Cities 2022 by Sirpa Pietikäinen, Christel Schaldemose, Karin Karlsbro, Bas Eickhout, Jadwiga Wisniewska and Idoia Villanueva Ruiz on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000039/2020) (B9-0014/2020). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: asks. Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen, President and representatives of the Commission. I am here today on behalf of the Committee on the Environment to talk about how we can make our cities greener. Green cities are more important than ever. They are central to addressing the major challenges we face in climate and environmental terms. Three quarters of the EU's population live in cities and suburbs and the proportion is still increasing. So we need to make an effort to help all the many people to live a cleaner and healthier and better life.  Greener cities are not just about making cities look greener, green cities are also about ensuring cleaner air, water and land, and about reducing noise and stress. Green cities are about ensuring longer and better lives, and it is about fighting the consequences of the climate crisis. Take air quality, for example. Urban air quality is one of the EU's biggest health challenges. Every year, hundreds of thousands of people die prematurely because of air pollution. And after air pollution, noise pollution is the biggest environmental cause of health problems.  We can do something about this if we do something to make sure our cities get greener. We can solve the problems of smart and simple and green investments. For example, we can plant natural noise guards, we can prevent soil erosion and flooding with good urban planning. We can also replace asphalt and concrete with planted soil and substrate through which the water can penetrate more easily. Green initiatives in cities can also help to safeguard our biodiversity, because with noise shields and flood defences and air purification initiatives, we can actually help our bees, butterflies, flowers and other fauna.  We really need to make a huge effort to do something about our cities. That is also why we in the Committee on the Environment wanted to ask this question. So to sum up: green infrastructure can address many of the challenges facing urban environments, such as the consequences of extreme weather events, loss of biodiversity, etc. And that is also why we would like to ask the Commission here today: is the Commission considering appointing or supporting the appointment of a year for greener cities in 2022? Indeed, we believe that this can help to raise awareness of how we can make our cities green. And how does the Commission wish to promote the exchange of the best initiatives around the major cities of the Member States? And what measures will the Commission take to help spread a green infrastructure? In other words, we in the Committee on the Environment want to make an effort for green cities and we want to ask the Commission what they intend to do to support this development of green cities.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this year probably more than ever, the two thirds of Europeans living in cities and urban areas have particularly valued the green spaces in our cities. During lockdown, we have rediscovered the comfort they provide, both physically and mentally, and during the extreme heat waves that have hit Europe this summer, we have enjoyed the cooling they brought. We all know greener cities are cooler, smarter and healthier. The ambition to green European cities and increase biodiversity in urban spaces was enshrined in the goals set out in the European Green Deal, which highlights the importance of urban green infrastructure for improving the quality of life in urban areas. Reflecting the importance of this subject, you propose in your draft resolutions a European Year of Greener Cities for 2022, which could possibly offer a platform to promote policies and to buy in support at city level to strengthen the implementation of EU environmental laws and policies and, thereby, to support delivery of the European Green Deal. I have taken note with great interest of this idea, and once adopted by this House, we will assess its feasibility and timing, also within the context of various city initiatives and programmes already under way or in the pipeline that aim to green urban areas and improve nature in cities. Now let me give you a few examples of the various initiatives and programmes through which we already today promote and scale up urban green infrastructure. The best known one, the European Green Capital, this year Lisbon and next year Lahti, and the Green Leaf awards. They reward and disseminate best practice in urban green infrastructure. The Green City tool offers guidance and advice, including on funding and capacity-building, and the soon-to-be-launched Green City Accord, which aims to support the EU biodiversity strategy for 2030 by encouraging greater nature and biodiversity actions in cities. Let me also mention the Urban Partnership on Sustainable Land Use and Nature-Based Solutions, which forms part of the Urban Agenda for the EU as well as the Urban Innovative Actions programme, that supports the testing of innovative ideas in cities, including in the area of green infrastructure. The EU MAES Initiative, which provides technical guidance for cities through the mapping and assessment of ecosystems and their services; the Horizon 2020 policy agenda for nature-based solutions and re-naturing cities, which aims to position the EU as a leader in innovating with nature; as well as the Horizon Europe mission on climate-neutral and smart cities, which will support 100 European cities in their systemic transformation towards climate neutrality and the Biodiverse Cities pilot project, which aims to enhance the use of green infrastructure in the urban context. More generally, EU funding for cities will provide important opportunities. Member States and regions can support green infrastructure through the EU cohesion policy, and will continue to do so in the upcoming programming period for cohesion policy, including through instruments such as the LIFE programme. Let me recall that scaling up the deployment of green infrastructure plays a key part in the recent EU biodiversity strategy for 2030, which recognises the importance of green urban spaces and calls on European cities of at least 20 000 inhabitants to develop ambitious urban greening plans by the end of 2021. The biodiversity strategy also contains a roadmap for planting at least 3 billion additional trees in the EU by 2030, which will be part of our upcoming forest strategy. This will be particularly beneficial in cities, not least as it will help us to cool urban areas. No less than 11 000 Natura 2000 sites designated under EU nature legislation are located within urban and peri-urban areas all over the European Union. Natura 2000 sites constitute the core of EU-level green infrastructure and often offer a strong basis for the development of urban greening plans. These may include measures to create biodiverse and accessible urban forest, parks and gardens, urban farms, green roofs and walls, tree-lined streets, urban meadows and urban hedges. This should help improve connections between green spaces, eliminate the use of pesticides in cities, and limit excessive mowing of urban green spaces and other biodiversity-harmful practices. Such plans could mobilise policy, regulatory and financial tools, and the Commission will support Member States and local and regional authorities through technical guidance and will help to mobilise funding and organise capacity-building. The Commission will also reflect this objective in the European Climate Pact. The process will be facilitated through the establishment of an EU urban greening platform in 2021 in close collaboration with cities and, of course, mayors. All these new commitments, both directly on urban greening but also the EU-wide commitments on nature protection and restoration, represent a major scaling-up of the deployment of green infrastructure across all of Europe. As a key element of our biodiversity strategy for 2030, green cities remain high on our political agenda, and I am counting on your, as well as on Member States’ and regions’, support to implement our ambitious goal to bring nature back to our cities. I look forward to working very closely with you on this important subject.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: In accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution has been tabled*. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday 17 September 2020. ___________ Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. "The green environments of European cities, municipalities and conurbations are important for our well-being and our economy. Green environments provide many services that are valuable to health and the economy, promote biodiversity and enable them to enjoy nature even for those who find it more difficult to get into the wild. Green neighborhoods are valuable and attractive. The design, construction and maintenance of green environments also play a major economic role in Europe. The sector employs people with difficulty. Biodiversity is in crisis and climate change is getting worse. The systematic addition of built green environments to cities and conurbations is urgently needed in Europe. Built green environments improve air quality, reduce sound pollution and air carbon dioxide content, mitigate the effects of extreme weather events, protect biodiversity well-built and encourage movement. In view of the impact of these important green environments, I propose that 2022 be designated the European Green Year. The European Year raises awareness of the importance of green spaces, emphasises the economic and environmental benefits of green environments and the role of improving the quality of life and influences zoning policy.  The importance of green spaces and nearby forests has dawned on many Europeans during the coronavirus crisis. When restaurants, museums, sports centres and other leisure facilities closed, for many, exercising in nature was one of the only ways to move outside the home. The coronavirus has further highlighted the need to add green areas to the urban environment where people can move freely and loosely, taking care of physical distance. The European Green Year 2022 is an even more important initiative due to the coronavirus.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The Green Cities Initiative is a necessity of our time. It contains many demands for the development of infrastructure in cities in this way, in order to improve the quality of life, air quality, reduce noise. The proportion of the urban population continues to grow and could reach 80% in 2020, and every year in the EU 430 000 people die prematurely from breathing polluted air.  Fortunately, we have been seeing a trend of restoring cities to nature for years. One of the many European cities that are undergoing such a transformation is Katowice, which is close to me. The city, which is the cradle of the Polish coal industry, has significantly improved the quality of life through infrastructure investments over the years. For many years, they have been implementing a programme of greening the city, showing that they attach the same importance to economic development to ensuring clean air for residents.  Today we need green infrastructure, the use of natural capital, but we must not forget the important role of ordinary infrastructure, which can improve the quality of life. That is why I tabled one amendment on district heating, which can make a significant contribution to improving air quality by reducing low emissions from homes; I know that this element is underestimated in many countries, but in my region of Europe it has a significant impact.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the need for an immediate EU humanitarian response to the current situation in the Moria refugee camp (2020/2781(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted.

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think I share the feelings of many of you watching the pictures from Moria after the fire, but also before the fire. And one of the goals I’ve been working on is to find and present a new pact on migration and asylum to be able to come to a solution where we can agree on a common European migration and asylum. One important aim is: no more Morias. (Applause) We should not accept people living under these conditions. I have said many times here in Parliament that the conditions in Moria are unacceptable and now it has just got worse. The pictures and reports remind us that the people in Moria are just like us – fathers, mothers, sisters and brothers, sons and daughters, people, men, women, old people, and all too many children who already had little and now have nothing. People running away from the fire, families torn apart, people sleeping on the burnt ground under the sky. What we know: on Tuesday at midnight fires started in several parts of Moria reception centre. A large part of the population ran into the surrounding areas and hills, others fled into the city of Mytilene and the vicinity of the Kara Tepe centre. On Wednesday two fires burnt down another part of the Moria centre. In practice, the Moria centre no longer exists. How these fires started is not yet clear, and I will not speculate. No one died or needed to go to hospital and that’s of course very good, luckily that’s the outcome. But 2 362 people are now in need of shelter, acute need. Our first priority must be the children. All remaining 406 unaccompanied minors in Moria have been transferred to the Greek mainland with the Commission’s help and financial support, and we did that the first day. I can today announce that the unaccompanied minors on the other islands will be moved to safety as well, and we have already started, as you know, the relocation of unaccompanied minors to other Member States and now we will step up on this and continue this coordination and relocation of unaccompanied minors. But I’m also worried about other vulnerable people – families with small children, the elderly and pregnant women. I have recently written a letter together with the Presidency and German Minister Horst Seehofer to all Member States arguing that we asked them to step in to do more voluntary relocation and more of this voluntary solidarity that is necessary now. Our immediate focus right now is to provide food and shelter and to prevent suffering, and to support the Greek authorities to this end. Last week Vice- President Schinas travelled to Greece to assess the situation. The Commission has been in constant contact with the Greek authorities and the German Presidency. On 12 September, Greece asked for assistance under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. Now we have 12 Member States that have already offered support – shelter, water, sanitation and hygiene products and medical assistance. Already more than 100 000 items have been included in this so far. Our Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC) is coordinating this effort, facilitating delivery and co-financing transport. Other Member States are providing medical teams and shelter on a bilateral basis. Reportedly, the support of food and water has been secured. Seven hundred tents and seven Rubb halls have now been installed to provide shelter which could house an estimated 5 000 people today. Vulnerable people and women with children are receiving priority. At the beginning of this week, 800 people were living in these tents. Progress is slow in part perhaps because all these people are being tested for COVID-19 and those that are found positive are being kept in isolation, but also because people are afraid to enter the new tent centre. We have to remember that these people are in a very, very difficult situation. Our agencies EASO and Frontex are on the ground offering support. For example, the offices of the Greek asylum service in Moria have been completely destroyed, but asylum interviews will resume in Lesbos in the coming days. These emergency measures build on our efforts over the last six months. You have heard me before saying in the beginning of my mandate that the conditions in these overcrowded reception centres on the Greek islands has been unacceptable. When we started, when I started and took office, there was more than 50 000 people living in the centres on the islands, and now there are half as many. In Moria in six months we have gone from 25 000 people to 12 000 people. It’s still too many, it’s still unacceptable, but I’ve pushed for change and numbers are going down thanks to the efforts of the Greek authorities and thanks to the efforts of the Commission. We have put in place a programme as you know to give unaccompanied minors a new chance and a new life in Europe, and one Member State also decided to welcome sick children with their families. So we are now on track to relocate 2 000 unaccompanied teenagers and children together with their families, and now we could top up that with the new pledges from Member States. Every week a plane is leaving to a welcoming Member State with these unaccompanied minors. In Moria, we went from 1 200 unaccompanied minors to 400, and these 400 have now also been moved to safety as I just said. In the last six months, we have also made efforts to build more and better reception facilities. You know, Moria has been destroyed and right now the acute task is to give shelter, food and medicine. A new permanent and proper centre is the priority, but there can be no more Morias. We need a fresh start on migration and this is the right moment, as President von der Leyen said yesterday in the State of the European Union. In her inspiring speech, she said: ‘Migration has always been a fact for Europe, and will always be. Throughout the centuries, it has defined our societies, enriched our cultures and shaped many of our lives, and this will always be the case.’ I could not agree more. That’s what I have always said: Moria is not normal but migration is normal. It’s something that we can manage. Moria is a leftover of the 2015 migration crisis, but times have changed. In 2015, almost two million people fled to Europe and crossed our borders irregularly. Now it’s 140 000 people irregularly arriving. In 2015, most refugees were from Syria and 90% received refugee status. Now the majority of irregular rivals – two thirds – are not entitled to international protection. The situation has changed, but the need for a common European policy and common European legislation to manage migration and asylum is still there. As President von der Leyen said yesterday, we want a constructive approach towards migration because it will always be with us. We need a humane and human approach. That means saving lives at sea is not optional. A closer link between asylum and returns, fighting smugglers, working with external parties and creating legal pathways to Europe. Welcoming people who have the right to stay, and helping them to integrate and be a part of our society. Solidarity with those countries who fulfil their legal and moral duties or are most under pressure. And with all Member States taking their share of the responsibility. (Applause)

name: Roberta Metsola
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the devastation on Moria, as you said, is horrifying; thousands are homeless, they are scared and they have lost everything. The combination of a continued migration influx, a pandemic, and Turkish sabre-rattling have made dealing with this emergency all the more challenging, and I really want to pay tribute to the Greek authorities, who are performing miracles in exceptionally difficult circumstances. Since last summer, as we heard, Greece with the EU’s support has managed, incredibly, to nearly halve the inherited numbers in the camp, from 22 000 to 12 000, and such is the scale of the challenge. Member States and the Commission have also been very quick to step forward with relocation pledges and immediate solidarity. I think in this discussion, we have to reiterate that the point is greater. We simply cannot have ad-hoc solidarity anymore. We need permanent instruments where every state plays its part, where meaningful solidarity is more than just a buzzword, where responsibility is truly shared, where lives are saved, where we completely reform Dublin, we improve our rate of return, we go after traffickers, we give people in need of protection a chance at a future without fear, where we strengthen our external border management, where we look at safe paths like resettlement that allow people a way out without getting on boats, where we invest in integration, where we end ghettos and tackle the causes fuelling extremism. As President von der Leyen pointed out, Moria cannot become yet another painful reminder of the (inaudible) Member States to step (inaudible). Three-year-old Alan Kurdi drowned ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the fire that has devastated the largest refugee camp on European soil is the last chapter of Europe's shame.  Since 2013, the Social Democrats have warned that Moria was hell. And it hasn't been acted on. The construction of another Moria cannot be the solution. The recovery of the dignity and rights of more than 12,000 human beings, many of them minors, requires their acceptance by national governments. How far are some willing to go to turn the Mediterranean into a cemetery? Are we not aware that in the Mediterranean not only lives are sinking, but we are also sinking the dignity of the European project itself? There are those who forget that the Mediterranean is the cradle of law. And refuge is a fundamental right. They despise without modesty the memory of Europe, this gesture of human solidarity as noble as asylum, provided by other countries to millions of European refugees who fled the wars that ravaged Europe on many occasions, and jeopardize the credibility of our European project. For years, the Council has blocked a common response to replace emergency solutions. And now we hope that the European Commission's proposal, which it will present next week, will propose a mandatory sharing mechanism based on responsibility and solidarity, as well as humanitarian visas.  You can't do good politics who doesn't have a good heart. And refusing to rescue people and refusing to regain their dignity proves not to be qualified to carry out this great responsibility that we have as Europeans.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, thank you, Madam Commissioner, and no thanks to the Council which is absent once again. I hear a lot these days that Moria is a failure of policy. Unfortunately it’s not a failure of policy, it is policy. This is what Member State governments have been doing deliberately. So they actually think it’s a success because Moria was supposed to be a deterrent and not a success, and therefore I would not want to improve the camps, we have to abolish camps. This is Europe, we don’t keep people in camps. How can we with moral authority judge, criticise the United States where Trump is building a wall, separating children from their parents, even forced sterilisation of women, if we let people drown, if we let them starve, if we let them live in the streets without even water, food and medicine? Can we look ourselves in the eyes? Now, this is a joint European responsibility, I’ll come back to that, but it’s also a Greek responsibility. What happened to the hundreds of millions of euros that were allocated to the Greek authorities earlier this year to improve reception conditions? How is it possible that amongst the 12 000 in Moria there were 2 000 who had already obtained their status, but they were homeless and forced to live in Moria? Why did the Greek authorities lock people up in the camp where there was Corona, which is basically arbitrary detention, which is illegal. Now, some governments have been very generous in taking in refugees, but some governments, including my own, have been heartless and stingy. But we also have to be honest colleagues because those governments cover parties which are EPP, S&D, RENEW and the Greens. And you know what, because they’re all scared of the people over there: the far right who are dehumanising human beings. But we should stop being scared and we should take our responsibility and listen to our citizens, because they are actually a lot less scared. Listen to all those local authorities in all our countries who say we are ready, we can do it, yes we can we can do it, ‘wir schaffen das’. And one last sentence, President, read my lips: Moria shall not be the model for the migration act that we will ... (The Chair cut off the speaker)

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, the fire in moria camp is a symbol of the failure of the Union's migration policies: 12,000 migrants were crammed into a place intended for only 3,000. Paralyzed by its indecision, the European Union has failed neither to prevent them from arriving in Greece, nor to host them with dignity. What is even more serious is that the Commission has not learned its lessons. In her speech on 16 September, Mrs von der Leyen explained that we must now open our arms to the new waves of migrants. It wants to repeal the Dublin Regulation to force European states to distribute the hundreds of thousands of migrants who will arrive in Greece and Italy. As an aspiring pump for immigration, we do not do better. Moreover, it wants to create legal channels of immigration, thus inflicting a kind of double punishment on European nations. The real solution, of course, lies at the opposite end of this sad programme of submission, it is to strongly resist the smugglers and the States, such as Turkey, which facilitate our submersion. But the Union will not be able to resolve it, at least not as long as it is led by the Merkel-Macron-von der Leyen trio. It is through strong political decisions and not through legal arguments that the peoples of Europe will take their destiny into their own hands.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, actually in this debate, far too few of the people who are most affected by this situation get to be heard: the refugees themselves. Our colleague Erik Marquardt is in Moria right now and he wanted to change that. That is why I want all of you to listen to the testimony that Zabi from Afghanistan gave to him, (Ms Reintke plays an audio message from her mobile phone into the microphone)  ‘Hi. My name is Zabi I’m from Afghanistan and I’m also one of the refugees who used to live in Camp Moria. Now that they have left Camp Moria, these refugees have been sleeping on the ground. This is an extremely horrible and heart-breaking situation.’ (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, we are here as Members of Parliament to help other people. We have other people to speak here. If we start that, we could have 450 million people speaking here! Ms Reintke, I am sorry, even though I understand what you want to say, please could you carry on in a different way – maybe reading it out or something?

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, if I must, I am going to read out the rest of the statement that Zabi from Afghanistan gave. He said: ‘If you think that the refugees are not suffering here, please see if you can come here with your own families, with your beloved ones. Cross the sea with a rubber boat and try to see if you can sleep on the ground with your beloved ones. Try it without having enough food, water or some sort of shelter. How can this happen? Honestly, we as refugees believed that human rights would be respected in Europe. The fact that we are refugees still doesn’t mean that we should be a burden on anyone’s shoulders. No, we can work as long as there are opportunities provided for us. We know how to even offer help because we have been through so much in life. We had heart-breaking reasons for leaving our countries. We had heart breaking reasons for leaving our families and our beloved ones behind. I don’t really know what else to say because these words should be enough to wake up those who take decisions.’ (Applause)

name: Εμμανουήλ Φράγκος
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, as you all know, Moria was burned by Islamist illegal immigrants, and the question is who coordinated them and with whom they cooperated; In any case, the fire in Moria confirms our view that coexistence with illegal immigrants is not only impossible. The solution we are proposing is simple and perfectly workable: We demand sealing our borders and transferring all of them to closed structures on uninhabited islands, away from the border with Turkey. Such islands are Yaros and Makronisos. They will remain there for up to six months until the deportation process is complete. And I am talking about deportation, because all these people are coming illegally from Turkey, a country that is neither a war nor a dangerous country. Therefore, they are not entitled to asylum in Greece. In conclusion, I want to convey to you the fear with which the Greeks who have next door a structure with thousands of people who create problems every day. And I want to ask you: Is it your duty to protect Greek and European taxpayers or illegal immigrants?

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mrs Johansson, European refugee policy has failed. The European Union of 27 Member States is shifting responsibility for its deadlocked policy to the host countries. Caring for asylum seekers is not the responsibility of Greece or Italy; it is a European responsibility, and the European Union must take its share of responsibility.  You have created in Greece a form of informal prisons, blatantly violating international refugee law. How long before we accept the burden of responsibility for the refugee crisis on the Greek islands? The solution to this humanitarian crisis is not another "Moria". We need a European response on the basis of true solidarity. It is imperative that an emergency Summit of the European Union be convened to resolve the humanitarian disaster. We need a sustainable new Pact on Asylum and Migration that is first and for all fair, based on a mandatory, automatic relocation of asylum seekers, and with a fixed predetermined rate of refugee allocation in all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Ιωάννης Λαγός
text: Unregistered. Madam President, Mrs President, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for her Johansson concealed in her speech— deliberately, I believe — the fact that the fire in Moria was not a random event but was an organised plan — according to the findings of our country's fire service, Greece — of at least five hundred organised illegal immigrants. In fact, in a subsequent identification, two of them were arrested and brought in, and they are seventeen years old; So this needs to be heard in the European Parliament, so that you know exactly what has happened. Mrs . Johansson said Moria was destroyed. Really, what was Moria destroyed from? From the citizens who have lived there all these years? From the inhabitants of Lesvos? Or illegal immigrants who, illegally, without asking anyone, have entered our country and are doing what they want? To end the fairy tale, we are calling for the immediate expulsion of all illegal immigrants and NGOs. And let us not forget that there were also messages from NGO officials inside Moria urging illegal immigrants to start this uprising and revolution. Are MEPs aware of this? Is the European Parliament aware of this? And one last question I have to ask everyone: Why don't illegal Muslims go to rich Muslim countries — Saudi Arabia, Qatar — and come to Europe, to which they are not accepted?

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this speaker and the previous speaker, what they’re saying amounts to hate speech. To accuse migrants of rape and to accuse them of being Islamists setting fire to the camp – this is hate speech. I think that this should not be allowed in this way in this Chamber. (Loud applause)

name: President. –
text: So a point of order. I consider that you want this checked by the Bureau, which we are going to do, and we are going to evaluate it.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, since 2015, we have been seriously concerned about immigration. An issue directly linked to revisionist Turkey, which blackmails us by tooling human souls. In dealing with this problem, ladies and gentlemen, we have failed. That's the truth. And Europe cannot fail twice, as Vice-President Schinas aptly observed recently.  We have before us a great challenge: to succeed, to continue together. There are no magic solutions but a single way: for all Member States to take action. President von der Leyen pointed this out emphatically yesterday in her important speech. The Greek government has taken substantial steps: effective guarding of external borders, speeding up asylum procedures, gradual decongestion of islands and progress in returns. But Greece cannot do it alone.  The new European Asylum System must mark a new era for migration; Immigration, ladies and gentlemen, is an essential European chapter, so we must not allow it to divide us.

name: President. –
text: Before we continue, I just want to say that we obviously have had differences within interpreting, so I just want to remind everyone that this is not the place where we distribute hate speech or false accusations. We will carefully look at what just happened in the last speeches.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Moria equals Europe’s shame. This is how we, the richest continent in the world, in 2020 welcome people fleeing war. Not by giving them protection but by stripping them of their human dignity. Gerald Knaus has rightly referred to the camp as the ‘Guantanamo for refugees’, and what happened in Moria last week is a shock but not a surprise. Moria was a time-bomb waiting to explode, and now 12 000 people lost the only thing they had left: their tents. Hope, they had already lost months’ ago. It’s a collective moral failure of the European Union by the Member States, leaving the burden all on the shoulders of the people living on the Greek islands, and some even wanting the misery to be a deterrent for others to arrive. But also by the Greek authorities who failed with EUR 2.6 billion in financial support to build decent humane reception facilities, and with the coast guard actively engaged in illegal and dangerous push-backs. With some empathy, solidarity and moral authority, we know what has to happen. Evacuation and relocation, and not only for the unaccompanied minors. Next week, the Commission will present its Migration Pact. Commissioner, we count on you. Let this finally be the moment of renewal of our principles. With a mandatory relocation of refugees and, as you said, no more Morias on European soil ever again.

name: Malik Azmani (Renew).
text: – Madam President, for years we have been debating incident after incident, whilst we should have been realising a renewed migration policy. Our current immigration policy is not fit for purpose. Recent fires in Moria are another cynical reminder that we must do much better. It is time to act.  Despite the efforts of the current Greek Government to improve the situation on Lesbos, we need a sustainable solution. We need a future-proof migration policy. Renew Europe already presented proposals in January. Proper migration management is about being in control, and it is a shared European responsibility. As long as migrants find their way to the EU via irregular routes, we need a proper response. We owe that to these people, but also to our citizens.  We need European reception centres at the EU external borders with adequate facilities. We need a first assessment at external borders to determine who is likely to get asylum and who is not. We need a joint effort to improve returns for those not eligible to stay and we need better and faster asylum procedures. Unfortunately, the Council is not joining us today in this important debate. My question would be, when will the German Presidency start negotiations on the proposals that will be presented next week? There is no time to lose.

name: Gianantonio Da Re (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the fire in the Moria refugee camp, which was home to almost thirteen thousand people, is a typical example of an announced catastrophe, which took place in the indifference and culpable inertia of the European Union.  The Moria refugee camp is in fact the failure of Europe's migration policy, the peak of which was reached in 2016 with the nefarious agreement between the European Union and Turkey, an agreement that dictator Erdogan has never respected and which has in fact turned the Greek islands into open-air prisons.  Turkey has been provoking Europe in two ways for months: by encouraging the passage of illegal migrants to Greece, while receiving EUROPEAN funding of EUR 6 billion to receive them, and by violating Greek and Cypriot sovereignty with drilling ships and warships. We must not give in to the threats of Turkey, which is not and will never be Europe. I can only agree with what President von der Leyen said yesterday, according to which migration policy is a challenge for Europe and that countries most exposed to migratory flows such as Greece and Italy must be able to count on the solidarity of the whole Of the European Union. Next week, the European Commission will present a new pact on migration and asylum. Europe cannot be absent at this stage.

name: Tineke Strik (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President. I wish to thank the Commissioner for her statement. The lacking statement of the German Presidency is unfortunately also a message. Yesterday, President von der Leyen emphasised the importance of our common values. Tell the children in Moria – exhausted after six months of confinement, lacking sufficient care and food, traumatised by the fire, sleeping on the street. Tell them about our common values. Share it with the refugee who said ‘we lost everything in Syria. We came for protection and we found ourselves in life—threatening circumstances right here. Take us out of this hell’. The strength and sincerity of our common values are best shown in the way we treat refugees, who rely on us. Until now the EU has failed this test.  So Commissioner, and also the Council – I hope they’re listening – please prove that these values also apply to refugees. I urge you, do not rebuild Moria on the islands as this will end up in the same misery. Ensure the right to asylum by acting firmly against the push—backs to Turkey. Take your responsibilities seriously and assure a real protective environment and procedure. Evacuate them from the islands, distribute them among the Member States and apply these harmful lessons to the new pact. We have no time to lose. (Applause)

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Moria refugee camp and the entire island of Lesbos have become hopeless hell for everyone: residents, immigrants and operators. The fire that broke out in the camp is only the latest incident and another serious problem for the Greek island. Moreover, according to the Greek authorities, to whom we are all close, it was precisely some of the camp's residents who started the fire, as had happened in the past, in protest against the situation in the camp. The situation in Lesbos is collapsing, as is the total inertia of the European authorities in other border areas of the Union, such as in our Lampedusa, Sicily.  It is a Europe that does not act to stop departures or even to repatriate the vast majority of immigrants who, unfortunately, are not refugees but irregulars, and as such must be deported.  A Europe under blackmail by human traffickers, a Europe that suffers from Erdogan's diktats, which uses migratory blackmail as a weapon of political pressure against Europe, combined with an increasingly aggressive military presence throughout the Mediterranean. Europe defends, or it will be too late.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we have heard hypocritical regrets — and I say so, 'hypocritical regrets' — on the part of the Commission in this House. The Moria fire is a long-heralded tragedy. It is not a coincidence, but a direct consequence of a criminal migration policy for which the European Union is guilty. Just like deaths in the Aegean, Mediterranean or Atlantic.  Migration policies that challenge refugees and migrants the right to have rights; and questioning their rights challenges those of all Europeans. We demand urgent and dignified relocation of the more than 13,000 people trapped in Lesbos; the prohibition of closed camps, which are genuine open-pit prisons; and a radical change in European migration policy so that there is no Moria camp, no camp of shame again. Take action now!

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Madam President, the tragedy in Moria is a prescribed crime with the policy of the European Union and the Greek governments guilty, which have created warehouses of souls and enabled the humanitarian and health risks to be intensified for people persecuted by wars and imperialist interventions, which they themselves — the European Union, NATO and the United States, that is — are carrying out. They have a firm objective of setting up a Reception and Identification Centre by turning Lesvos and other Aegean islands into permanent concentration camps and, in order to achieve this, they are enlisting the MATs and intensifying the repression against refugees and islanders.
