Despite hypocritical concerns seeking to obscure the European Union's responsibilities, as long as the European Union-Turkey agreement and the Dublin Regulation remain in force, the problem will persist and grow. To permanently close Moria and the other KYT of the islands. To organise immediately the transfer of refugees to the mainland, in compliance with the health protocols. To ensure human safety and hygiene conditions for their temporary accommodation, with the possibility to apply for asylum after reaching the countries of their final destination.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is not the first time we have spoken about Moria, but it must be the last time. Poor facilities in overcrowded camps, it is a disgrace to Europe. And what next? In the short term, that is clear. Asylum seekers affected by the fire must be helped quickly and the Greek Government must be able to count on our support. Better reception in Greece and redistributing, including among other Member States. It is good that so many Member States have already offered help.  However, for a real solution, we need a genuine European effective asylum and migration policy. Working with other countries to prevent people without prospects of asylum from making life-threatening journeys on rickety boats. Efficient and just procedures at our borders to quickly determine whether someone is actually fleeing war. Because, as the Commissioner rightly said, with two thirds of the people currently arriving in the European Union, that protection is not necessary, and that too is part of this debate, which we really need to be more honest about.  Decent reception and integration of genuine refugees is absolutely crucial. We need to do much more about this, but at the same time we really need to ensure that we finally have a system whereby people who do not receive asylum actually return to their country of origin. There is a great deal of support in our society for the reception of vulnerable refugees, we have seen this in the aftermath of the Moria fire and we should be proud of that. It is up to us here in this House, together with the Council, which is unfortunately absent, and with the European Commission to ensure that that support is not lost in the future.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her No perspective, no hope, no way out! The conditions in Moria have long been unbearable for all people on the island. Moria also symbolizes the failure of all member states to implement our values and international law in solidarity.  Overwhelmed regions are denied real solidarity, member states disregard laws and values without consequence, people seeking help are denied fundamental rights, even without consequence. This is a political shambles. We are expecting the Commission's new migration pact shortly. We could now sweep out the shards together, dare a new departure. Next generation – but that does not mean "continue like this" with deterrence through unworthy conditions, push backs and people's immobilizers. What is at stake is not only the future of the refugees, but our Europe, our values. That is why it is all the more important that there should be movement in the Council, that we work together to shape a reform based on solidarity. A reform that includes a distribution key, coordinates and does not criminalise maritime rescue, organises migration and diversity as an opportunity and, above all, prevents a second Moria.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Commissioner Johansson, I would like to thank you sincerely for the work you are doing. I think it's commendable.  However, with all due respect, I do not know how Commissioner Schinas can say that Moria represents the Europe that we must change, after five years of putting money, from the European institutions, to that inhumane spawn. I don't know how you can think about building another macrofield in Lesbos. I don't know how, after five years, we can think about repeating the scheme, repeating the system. Moria was hell. Even for the Greek officials who were there it was hell. And we must think of all the people who want refuge in Europe and we must also think of the inhabitants of the islands like Lesbos. Because that scheme is socially toxic too.  Let's not believe another Moria from Moria's ashes. No model of migration policy can include the humiliation and vexation of human beings. And by the way, there's Samos, there's Chios, and Parliament must decide to send an urgent mission to the islands now.

name: Teuvo Hakkarainen (ID).
text: – Mr President, the inhabitants of the Moria camp set fire to and burned down their own camp. Some of the camp's residents also tried to stop the firefighters from working. As a reward, arsonists can get a ticket to Europe. This is probably the latest way to make a violent landing on our continent. Ships from various aid agencies continue to sail in the Mediterranean, which, despite behind the scenes, are people smugglers. They lurk off the coast of Libya and bring rubber boat ers aboard. Why are they being allowed into Europe? The right address is where they came from. One can see the day when European decision-makers come to their senses and the borders are closed to migration! Do you really think the visitors will stop by receiving?

name: Damien Carême (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Shame on you, shame on European governments and their shabby apothecary accounts. 12,000 human beings, after living for months in filthy and shameful conditions, are now left to fend for themselves on the island of Lesbos. And what are European governments doing? They agreed to welcome a few dozen isolated miners. Shame. Shame on the Greek government, which, at this very moment, while refugees are being transferred to a new camp, forbids Doctors Without Borders access to its clinic. Shame on this Europe unable to welcome the 24,000 refugee seekers stranded on the Greek islands. Shame on our leaders who, for months, years, have remained deaf to our repeated calls for solidarity and relocation from Greece. Shame on those in this Chamber who distill fear, cultivate the divide, and to those who out-bid by electoral calculations, in defiance of the most basic human rights. Shame, but also immense hope.  Hope, seeing the demonstrations in Germany, where European citizens are chanting the truth: we have room. Yes, we have room for human beings who make up barely a quarter of the spectators in a football stadium, just 0.005% of the European population. Hope, seeing these municipalities in France, Germany and elsewhere, who say they are ready to welcome them. Hope, in talks this week with young European citizens committed to human rights and who want to change the policies and speeches of European leaders on immigration. So stop these nauseating speeches and deadly policies on behalf of the citizens. Stop shame and bring hope and solidarity. This is what Europe needs more than ever. Let us implement long-term solutions to deal with the structural fact of migration, instead of providing miserable answers to a situation that some are trying to make believe is only cyclical.

name: Helmut Geuking (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Human tragedies and human tragedies have not only taken place in Moria since the fire, but this condition has been known for years. We are aware of the problem and we have remained silent – mostly silent.  It is now time to finally react in a sustainable way, so that Europe reacts sustainably, because the refugee policy will accordingly become even more acute. In other words, we proposed at the time that we said that we do not need to build refugee camps, but proper refugee cities with infrastructure – that is, schools, daycare centres and hospitals – where people are taken in, where people are properly housed and cared for, and where an asylum procedure can then be carried out.  And a positive asylum decision means introducing people into Europe, and a negative asylum decision means that people must return to their home countries in order to build these countries, because that is where they are urgently needed. Otherwise, we will destabilise other regions, and this will make matters worse.  In the 21st century, we can build refugee cities in the shortest possible time, and we are able to do so, and we should do so as urgently as quickly as possible.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Moria is not an unfortunate development. Moria is a political choice made by the Commission, together with the Member States. It is meant to deter, dehumanise and treat people as if they were just not human. Here in the European Parliament, I would like to say that it is shameful that my country, Sweden, has not offered to receive a single person who is affected in Moria. But it is also shameful that the Commission is saying right away that we are now going to build a new camp on Lesbos. We're not going to have any camps. We're closing the camps. We're going to evacuate Moria. We are going to agree on a policy, a model to be presented next week, based on sharing joint responsibility for reception – a dignified reception – in which we treat people who come to Europe in the way that we ourselves would like to be treated. It's no harder than that, and in it there can be no camps. As a former colleague said: it is 2020. We're in Europe. This continent should have no camps.

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: Madam President, the Moria camp was designed to accommodate 2,800 people. When it caught fire, 13,000 refugees were living in the camp, the largest in Europe, in inhumane conditions, without clean water, rationed food, a toilet for 150 people and a shower for 500. When the camp was closed because of COVID, violence increased and mental health problems exploded. Who is responsible for this humanitarian disaster?  The European Union can no longer hide its responsibility, our asylum policy is directly responsible for this shame. What was burned in Moria camp is our collective dignity. We urgently need a common reception programme, a much more inclusive asylum policy that obliges all EU states to take their share of responsibility and takes into account the capacity of regional and local governments. Wouldn't Spain accept one of Moria's refugees? Without an effective defence of human rights, the European Union is useless, let us not forget.

name: Λουκάς Φουρλάς (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what we have witnessed in Moria is cause for sadness and concern. But for some of us it was expected, and we've been warning about them for a very long time. When immigration was loaded on the shoulders of some Member States, with most of us safely criticising by pulling their tails out of responsibility, really, didn't you expect what happened? When Greek officials pointed out to us, here in Brussels, that Greece cannot bear the burden on its own and, in response, we even accused it of crimes without any proof, really, did you not expect all that happened?  Here is another truth, Commissioner. Do you know that in my country, Cyprus, today, 3.8% of the population, in a semi-resident country, are asylum seekers and refugees? If something happens there, who are they going to blame for this Hemicycle? Do you not think it is time, after all this, to convince some of our countries to finally assume their responsibilities? As long as they don't understand it, we'll have phenomena like what we saw in Moria, and the responsibility is now collective.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Johansson, moria's tragedy is perfectly predictable and was announced: 12,000 people homeless, without medicines... There have been 25,000 locked up in a field of misery, and that is completely incompatible with Europe, whether in Lesbos, or in Lampedusa, or in Arguineguín, Canary Islands. Shame, shame, Schande, honte, shame is the cry expressed by European citizens who think that, if we are not able to close all the 'Morias', what should be closed is this European Parliament, the European Commission, the whole of the European Union. But the answer can only be to change the gaze, which means changing policy: from a policy of rejection to a human and humanitarian policy. In the long run, this requires addressing the ultimate causes, in the Middle East, in Africa, in the Mediterranean, including Turkey.  In the medium term, it calls for the new European Pact on Immigration and Asylum, with binding solidarity, shared responsibility, a European mechanism for saving and rescuing at sea that does not criminalize the rescue of lives. And legal avenues and humanitarian visas.  But in the short term, the Greek authorities must be required to respect human rights and, of course, hot returns must be said no. But urgent, non-fragmentary or rachytic re-stay is also needed: four hundred unaccompanied minors, 1,600 before the end of the year. Compared to the 12,000 overcrowded, mandatory and permanent binding re-injection is needed in all Member States of the European Union. Only then will it be possible not to more Moria, never again.

name: Jan-Christoph Oetjen (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mrs Johansson, I would like to thank Mrs Johansson for her work on this Moria is a disgrace to Europe, and you have gone into this disaster with your eyes on it. I think we all knew what could happen there. It is quite clear to me that people are entitled to adequate accommodation, access to medical care and due procedure under the rule of law. Now, however, we must not only look backwards, but also forwards.  You have announced, Mrs Johansson, that you want to do a pilot project on Lesbos – together with the Greek Government – and that a new camp will be set up. It is clear to me that such an institution on Lesbos can only be temporary, can only serve to make an initial determination of identity, to make an initial medical care, and then to distribute it further, to distribute it to other countries in Europe or to bring it to the Greek mainland.  There must be no permanent facility on Lesbos, where people wait months or years for their asylum procedure to be processed. This must not happen again, but we need a mechanism in which all the countries of Europe participate and show solidarity.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Our hypermoralists here in Parliament are once again outdoing themselves with demands to take in illegal migrants as a reward for arson. Matches as a ticket to the EU – what a fatal signal to the world!  Last year, 1,500 migrants were taken from Moria, and the following day, the camp was replenished from Turkey with 1,500 new migrants. This is unsustainable, it is suicide. The Green Marquardt is more in Moria than here in Parliament. What does he actually represent, what do you actually represent? European citizens or illegal migrants?  Who thinks of the residents of Lesbos who have been suffering for years or of our European citizens, who will change massively as a result of this illegal influx? What follows now– what a coincidence – is a new migration pact that is supposed to legalise illegal migration. We will be overrun if we do not finally close the borders. And you supposed pro-Europeans, with von der Leyen at the helm, will go down in history as the eu's gravediggers.

name: Damian Boeselager (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I say to the Commissioner: Moria showed it clearly, but we see the same across the continent. We deliberately create suffering and hardship in camps to dissuade people from coming. We try to match their suffering outside Europe by creating suffering on European soil, traumatising people with hardly any shelter, sustenance and medication. I call this the policy of ‘deterrence by systematic suffering’.  Today, I plead to you for two things. First of all, please help all the people of Moria to travel to communities across Europe who are very happy to welcome them. And second, I plead to you to ensure that something like Moria can never happen again. I repeat your call, ‘no more Moria’, but I would also extend it. No more Chios, no more Samos, no more camps in general. Don’t finance camps with EU money. Close them all.  (Applause)

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the Moria countryside is really a tragedy, but it is a tragedy that existed.  It has been burned by those inside, because they wanted to accelerate their illegal entry into a continent that cannot welcome all other continents, no long as we have here a number of people representing, with that moral superiority, it seems, those who want to welcome everyone who wants to come. Because they don't fit.  And let's see if we respect the Europeans a little bit. Let us see if we respect the Greeks, who are suffering, because they have destroyed their habitat in Lesbos and so many other islands. Why don't we go to the origins? Why are we not going to see Turkey, which has been manipulating these refugees, these illegal immigrants who accumulate there, who have none of them entitled to asylum, who should have been deported and taken to their home countries a long time ago, but who are used by Turkey? Why did everyone condemn Turkey yesterday and now draw a resolution where there is not a single sanction against Turkey? Why is there not a penalty against Turkey? Why don't we go to the origin and not cry and try to bring all continents here to Europe to destroy Europe?

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, if the above situation was already catastrophic, the fire and destruction of the Moria refugee camp makes it necessary to urgently rethink the situation of refugees trapped in Lesbos.  Our group has no complexes in saying we don't want another field like Moria's. Moria was not a foster camp. It was a concentration camp, suspension of basic human rights, overcrowding and unhealthiness, and that is why it is necessary to consider the emergency evacuation of all refugees in Moria.  In this regard, it is necessary to relocate all asylum seekers safely in other Member States of the Union, because it is a responsibility of the Union. And these actions must be done as soon as possible, without waiting for another maximum emergency situation, as was about to happen last Tuesday. Hundreds of municipalities and regions of the Union have expressed an interest in receiving asylum seekers and this requires the activation of a relocation plan, including the creation of the necessary infrastructures. And it is the Member States that must show will, but it is the Commission that has to exert positive political pressure to make this possible. It is urgent, we must do so now, and let us hope that action in this regard will open up a new European migration policy that considers the right to migrate as a basic human right.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: We are a place of debate here, of political debate, and also of a sharp debate, we have very different opinions, and that is right and proper that we are expressing this here.  I must admit that, as a German, I find the mention of the word 'concentration camp' to be highly borderline in this context. But I don't have to decide that on my own now. That is what the Bureau will do. But I think it has happened several times now. I would like to remind you of some historical awareness.

name: Lena Düpont (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have heard a lot in recent days about the failure of the European Union, but who has actually failed? There was a Greek government under Tsipras that has watched for too long as conditions on the islands deteriorate. There are Member States in the Council that are leaning or in fundamental opposition. In between are desperate Member States that bear the burden on behalf of everyone else. So what is part of the new CEAS? Order and humanity that intertwine. Let us not delude ourselves, and moria is not the only example of this, but it is difficult to maintain our humanitarian claim in the chaos. That is why Mitsotakis' decisions in recent months have been the right one – streamlining procedures, improving conditions on the islands, sending clear signals to Turkey that we will not allow ourselves to be blackmailed. Let us support them where we can, with the resources they need. What Europe needs now? A chain of responsibility, starting in the countries of origin and transit, through a functioning border management system with a proper border procedure on which everyone can rely, which clearly distinguishes between vulnerability and other motivations, a solidarity-based reception for vulnerable people and the consistent repatriation of those who are not. My request to the Council: let us finally bring it to an end, so that we no longer have to go from emergency solution to emergency solution.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the situation of Moria should never happen again on EU soil. These leftovers, as you mentioned, are indeed shameful and still today we need to address the root cause of migration by framing a real EU policy in our neighbourhood where migration originates. Syria, Libya, Sahel and sub-Saharan Africa – we cannot remain absent. So we need definitely to introduce a new control of European funding to governments and NGOs with quality standards. We need to provide legal and safe ways in EU consulates and embassies – for example, even in Turkey, which is a safe country to receive refugees – and make sure they can approach the EU.  Third, strong conditionality for European Member States that share the burden in solidarity but also to make sure that we will use economic leverage for those EU Member States that do not share the burden.  And fourth, I do welcome the commitment to abolish the Dublin Regulation, by Ursula von der Leyen, but still there is a contradiction since the EPP encompasses parties from Member States with mentalities like Orbán’s in approaching the migration crisis.

name: Hilde Vautmans (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that I have visited refugee camps many times. Next week – I invited you but you can’t come – I will go to Dunkirk not far away from here, because another ‘Jungle’ is starting to unfold there.  Honestly, these camps are a shame for Europe. I always say, if we put our dog or our cat in such conditions, animal rights organisations would be at our door, but we put human beings in camps like that. Next week, you will come with a new migration strategy. I have one specific question for you because a lot has been said by my good colleagues. I want you to pay a lot more attention to the unaccompanied minors. You know that Europol stated that 10 000 went missing in Europe. Please, Commissioner, pay specific attention to these children. If we don’t protect them, who will?  (Applause)

name: Diana Riba i Giner (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Johansson, what has happened in Moria and what happens on a daily basis on Europe's southern border is well known. And it is a consequence of the inoperability and shameful role of the European Union, which, for years, has tolerated the containment of migrants in inhumane conditions.  What does the European Union expect to act? For what? What we're crying about here today could be solved. That is why, today, the European Union and the States should ensure the relocation of all moria refugees; present, without further delay, permanent and binding relocation mechanisms, and end the violations of rights suffered by migrants and asylum seekers.  We cannot fall into the cynical attitude of giving lessons in justice and human rights to third countries, when it is obvious that we do not respect them eer at our borders or in several of our Member States.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, thank you Commissioner for being here, but let me tell you, Moria is not a accident, it is the concrete result of migration policies and the lack of asylum policies in the European Union. Moria is not now, it is already several years, although everyone tries to close their eyes and Moria yes, is the most visible result of what has been a shameful policy.  While we are here talking about thousands of people who are still homeless, without medicines, without food, and among these people more than 3,000 children continue to sleep in the open, and we really need to bring to our political intervention what has been missing. These people cannot be subjected to zero dignity, to zero humanity, as if they were not people as we are.  I would like to see, on the part of the European States, the same rejection of arms sales to the conflicting territories that I see when they reject these people from trying to reach European countries. This is the result of our shame, but it is not mandatory that it be so. Please don't let another camp be built in Moria. We will finally have a solidarity policy and respond to these people now.

name: Karlo Ressler (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, the Moria fire is only the last indicator, a symbol of shortcomings in the European system of migration and asylum, but we can no longer close our eyes. We cannot avoid facing the difficult issue of migration and we must do so seriously, responsibly and comprehensively and without any improvised solutions.  A prerequisite for all this is simply effective protection of external borders. That is why it is encouraging that today, unlike five years ago, we have protection at both the Greek and Croatian external borders of the European Union, but also that the European Union clearly supports the policy of preventing irregular, uncontrolled and versed migration. The new system of migration and asylum must be humane to those who need support, determined towards those who are not entitled to asylum, to international protection, but also completely uncompromising to traffickers and smugglers who profit from someone else's suffering.

name: Pietro Bartolo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, have you seen the burnt-out camp in Moria? A runaway child asked her father, "Is it true that we're going to die?" What can a father answer? What do you want a father to answer? But we must respond, with extreme harshness. The sad spectacle that Europe is offering is unacceptable: a sad sight! A moral and political imperative obliges us to call, now and immediately, for the immediate evacuation of the camp and the acceleration of relocation from the islands to the Member States, especially the most vulnerable children.  It is good that Merkel is committed to welcoming 2750 people from the islands, but we need a change in the asylum system. Let us be clear: on the eve of the Commission's migration pact, I say to the governments that the credibility of the institutions is at stake here. The rules must be changed: we need a compulsory solidarity mechanism that provides for automatic relocation and sanctions for those who do not comply with it. You don't need to build new fields, you don't need to! Instead, structural reforms are needed, and they are needed now, not in decades' time.

name: Barry Andrews (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I visited Moria this time last year – 12 months ago – and you can’t help but be struck by the astonishingly poor conditions. I’ve been to lots of refugee camps around the world, and these are the worst conditions I’ve seen. I was struck by the violence, by the children who can’t get an education, by the sanitation, and by the smell of the camp. When you walk in, you can’t believe that you’re on EU territory. It has got worse in the last 12 months. Now we’ve had this fire, and COVID-19 on top of it.  I have some hope, though. I have some faith listening to President von der Leyen giving her excellent speech yesterday, when she talked about a progressive migration and asylum pact. I have faith in Chancellor Merkel – notwithstanding the Group of the European People’s Party’s (PPE) continuing tolerance of Mr Orbán – that we can build a safe and fair Europe that welcomes those who are fleeing for their lives and those who are seeking a better life. I would like to go back to Moria. I cannot do so, but it is as much about the people in the camp as it is about us and the people we aspire to be, and the values we aspire to protect.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President! Everyone knows that with refugees and migrants it does not pass. We also know that it will pick up. The vast majority of refugees are and remain in their neighbourhoods, but many – probably more now, when we really start to see climate refugees – will be looking for Europe and we have a legal obligation to treat them properly. Climate action in areas affected by natural disasters, emergency aid for war victims and development aid in low-income countries works and needs to be strengthened, but is far from solving the whole problem. There will be many more coming to us and we need to develop common strategies within the European Union. Everyone can join us, including my own Denmark, which I am not very proud of right here. What is at stake now is not the risk of the European Union being flooded to strangers, it is our values, our humanity. If we do not protect it and extend our fellow human beings in need to the helping hand, even by accepting them, we are in far greater danger. If there is no compassion and mercy in a society, it becomes a grim place to live. And remember now: no one can help everyone, but everyone can help someone.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Moria was already hell before it burned. Moria's fire is not the news, its very existence is: more than 13,000 people in a field with capacity for 4,000. It's not an accident. It is the direct consequence of the European Union's nefarious, hostile, migration and border policies. We continue to export weapons to countries of conflict, continue to expose resources and fuel wars from which millions of people flee, and when they arrive, we put them in tents in inhumane conditions and deny them the right to seek asylum. We must immediately relocate each and every one of these people, not just children, and not just Moria, also Samos, Chios, Calais and all the fields that extend throughout our territory. We must end the militarization of borders. We must fight the mafias effectively, offer legal and safe routes and ensure a migration and asylum pact. Yesterday, the President of the Commission said in this House that the European Union had challenges ahead. The European Union has challenges and obligations today, here in the present: respecting and complying with international law. We can't look to the future watching death pass. We are complicit and today that complicity kills.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is depressing, it is shocking what has happened in the Moria refugee camp. Quite frankly, it is simply a disgrace to the European Union that such conditions can prevail within Europe at all.  This has not only been known since the fire, as has been the case before. And we have not yet averted moral insolvency in Europe. The situation in Moria is another humanitarian fire in Europe. But it's not just about migration. There are many fires. They are reinforced by Corona, and they are becoming more: the high unemployment, growing social inequality and the resulting hopelessness of the people. We need – and I expect this when we implement Ursula von der Leyen's speech – an overall package that is presented to us: aid on the ground – outside the borders of the European Union – effective external border protection, an agreement with third countries, burden-sharing and a European asylum and migration policy, which also deserves the name and corresponds to Ursula von der Leyen's speech.

name: Claudia Gamon (Renew).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For so long we have known about terrible unsustainable conditions in Greek refugee camps, and for days some have been watching, unmoved, as families with children have to sleep and live in the dirt after this devastating fire in forests, on the streets. Young Europeans write to me every day who, like me, do not want to see that this is Europe, that this should be our values. I am also ashamed of Austria, a country governed by conservatives and greens, for refusing to accept even children.  There must be no more Moria in the future. We must also make the Greek Government accountable. Europeans, Europeans and Citizens of the Union expect their tax money to be used to make human European policies. We need a European authority in the future, we need a European asylum and migration system, we need European values that are being lived!

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the fire burned the Hotspot Moria, which was not a good place to live, it was overcrowded. It is our duty to respond. I am therefore glad that the Commissioner has clearly said: 'No more new Hotspot Moria'. I am glad that the European Commission, in cooperation with the Greek Government, will help to prepare better conditions for life, whether it be a hotspot or another accommodation facility that is more favourable to these people. That's not a long-term solution. The long-term solution is, as we know, the acceleration of asylum processes, an effective return policy, the protection of external borders, the fight against smugglers and, above all, assistance to those who really need this help. I hope that the Czech Government will finally decide to participate, because there are also citizens in the Czech Republic who are in solidarity. I appeal to colleagues from the Liberal and Socialist parties to appeal to the Liberal Prime Minister and the Socialist Interior Minister, who claim that there are no unaccompanied children and minors in greek camps. Please, we want to help, too.

name: Samira Rafaela (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that 13 000 human lives are damaged and traumatised, left without shelter, access to water, food and medical care. This has all happened on the doorstep of our Union – the Union that globally promotes human rights and is ready to act in cases of human rights violations.  What about the violations of human rights within our Union? It is time for serious self—reflection. I’m ashamed, as a Member of the European Parliament and as the daughter of a migrant who came to Europe for a better future. How can we look at ourselves in the mirror? Resolutions for humane migration policies have been on the table for years now, but several Member States are walking away from that table. Do you understand the fundamental principles of this Union? Your denial is putting lives in danger. Madam Commissioner, what are we going to do? Because we are all accountable. Our values, including the protection of human rights, are not negotiable.  (Applause)

name: Ylva Johansson
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, (inaudible) people in Moria are like us. I think being a human being is having the ability to look another person in his or her eyes and understand some of the conditions that they are living under. This is really important, and Ms Kountoura brought one of those voices here, which is important.  Moria does not exist anymore, and there should be no more Morias – no more camps like Moria. Of course, Moria should not be restored.  We need proper reception facilities, efficient and fair processes. We need clear rules, and people should not be left in limbo.  During the debate – and I thank you very much for your engagement here – many of you asked for mandatory solidarity, and that of course is something that we need. Ms Metsola said it well that we can’t have ad hoc solidarity anymore, and mandatory solidarity will be part of the upcoming pact that I will present next week. I can also answer another question. There will be a clear child perspective in the pact that I will present next week. It’s obvious that we need that. I must say that, of course, not all migrants have the right to stay in the European Union. Those that are not eligible to stay have to be returned, but all migrants have dignity and rights. Ms García Pérez rightly said that, and they have to be treated properly. Together we need to stand up for and protect the right to apply for asylum. To be honest, this right is under threat. Asylum applicants have the right to a proper process, and we have to make sure that they have that. Of course, we also have to make a distinction between those who have the right to stay, and those who have not and have to be returned, but in a proper and dignified way.  Ms In’t Veld said something important here, early in the debate. She encouraged us not to be afraid. We should be proud Europeans. We should act in line with our values. We should act as global leaders. Migration is normal. Of course, it has to be managed, and to be able to do so we need to agree on a common European migration policy. To be able to agree on a common migration policy we need to de-dramatise migration policy.  The EU is not in a migration crisis, but some migrants are in crisis. One reason that we lack this common policy is this dramatisation of the issue. One reason for this failure, for many years, to agree on a proper compromise is that migration policy has been dramatised and seen as something very special.  But we are policymakers, and you are legislators, and we are able to give support and respect the dignity and rights of people. To be able to do that, we need to be calm and pragmatic. I count on your support for the process of the proposal that I will put forward next week. Thank you for the debate.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. I don’t know if you have the same problem with your interpretation as we have up here, but we are going to give the technicians the possibility to check that and hopefully to solve the problem. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, what happened in the Moria camp is something I warned about at the beginning of the migrant crisis. It was clear that migratory pressures and overcrowded refugee centers near settlements would provoke the reaction of locals. Colleagues on the left talk about a political solution to the crisis, talk about accepting and displacing immigrants "in solidarity," but conveniently forget that they, together with Mrs. Merkel, invited everyone from everywhere to come to Europe to turn it into a huge camp for illegal immigrants. It is extremely hypocritical to talk about solidarity when certain countries, with their actions, have caused destabilisation in the Middle East and North Africa. Then these countries made their decision selfishly, but when the time comes to hold us accountable, they already ask us for solidarity. The solution is one thing – all those fleeing war and have nowhere to return can seek refuge. All other immigrants must be immediately repatriated. We must prosecute all organisations and people helping to get illegal immigrants into Europe. More support for FRONTEX, more support for frontline countries, more funding to protect the EU's borders.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI)
text: in writing. In recent years, we have always called for European management of migratory flows, a fair distribution of responsibilities among the Member States, denouncing the inadequacy and inefficiency of current European migration policies and the opportunism and blackmailing attitude of the Turkish Government, which have put a strain on border countries such as Greece, which are more exposed to migratory pressure. More than an announced tragedy, Moria is an emblem of the denial of those values on which the EU is founded, both because of the degrading and inhumane conditions in which people were kept in the centre, and because of the unsustainable migration and asylum system that has been put in place. In addition to immediate aid and assistance to be provided after the tragedy, in particular to the most vulnerable groups such as families with minors, the elderly and pregnant women, the hope is that the new pact on migration and asylum will provide new tools and policies that do not repeat the mistakes of the past and have new cases such as moria's.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Moria was a forgotten place in Europe and there must have been a great tragedy for us to start the subject of migration again. Only this time we cannot stop at exchanging views. I look forward to the Commission's proposal , the Migration and Asylum Pact, with a look forward to introducing a quota system for the number of migrants to be admitted to each Member State.  There have been many voices during the debate calling for solidarity and humanism, and over the last 5 years we have left Greece alone with the problem! I feel personally guilty because my country did not accept anyone in 2015. Without specific provisions requiring the admission of migrants, we cannot be sure that the situation will not happen again.  I agree with Ursula von der Leyen, who said that migration is part of our European history. Moreover, this phenomenon will be multiplied m.in climate change, and we are still unable to accept the category of so-called climate refugees. Why do we create reactionary rather than preventive policies? It is already known that we can counter the barbaric business of smugglers transporting refugees in inhumane conditions across the Mediterranean by creating humanitarian corridors.  Nor would the tragedy in Moria be if there was an efficient asylum policy, today the application procedure takes several years. Let's remember that places like Moria can't be created. I call on the Member States to accept refugees left behind on the streets of Lesbos, it is our Christian and civic duty.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The fires that broke out in the early hours of 9 September in the Moria refugee camp have reduced to ashes what was the reception centre for those seeking help and a better life in Europe. More than 12,000 people, including children and adolescents, were detained there in inhumane conditions in a camp with a capacity considered four times that of various human rights organizations. If before COVID-19 the conditions in this field were already manifestly precarious, they worsened even more with the confinement of the camps, endangering the health and even life of the people who were there. These fires in a refugee camp expose a reality that reveals well the consequence of the implementation of EU migration policies, the construction of "Fortress Europe" that is wary of the most basic human rights or the absence of legal and safe routes. At the moment, it is imperative to help, welcome and integrate these people into society and, at the same time, to ensure that accidents do not occur in other refugee camps, ensuring hygiene and health conditions as well as health services, while people are not taken from the camps to safer and more humane places.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law under Rule 144 of the Rules of Procedure. I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches in all the debates of this part-session and that no blue cards are accepted. The subject of the first debate on six motions for resolutions is 'Situation in the Philippines, in particular the case of Maria Ressa' (2020/2782(RSP)*. -------------- * See Protocol.

name: Hannah Neumann (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think we have the wrong order because I was actually the one negotiating these resolutions. There must be a mistake, but if the author gets the first word that should be me.

name: President. –
text: I have Urbán Crespo, Bielan, Neumann, Fuglsang, Wiseler-Lima and Guetta as the order, and it’s being signalled to me that is the correct order. I cannot check that. We have four points of order now. I don’t know if this really makes sense to discuss the order because there are very few people watching us live. You are going to put it on to your social media anyway, only yours, but OK, if it’s important, yes. Who wants to reply? There have been so many.

name: Frédérique Ries (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I’m sorry but we have exactly the same problem for the next debate on Dr Mukwege, which is that the first three authors to take the floor have not participated in the negotiations.  I don’t understand why we don’t do things like we used to do them: take the authors in the order of importance of the groups. At least you could do that. It’s completely awkward to have as a first orator taking the floor somone from ID who has been completely absent. This is a problem for some of us as we have no clue what they think on the issue.  So it’s more than just a cosmetic problem. I think it’s really problematic. It’s symbolic who takes the floor in the first place, and that’s not the kind of signal we want to send to the person who we are defending today. So please convey this huge concern to the people responsible for that. Don’t talk to us about the rules, because rules have limits and these are not good rules.

name: President. –
text: I have a problem here, of course, because I wasn’t present. I completely understand what you are saying and appreciate that you tell us. The idea obviously is that the order is by the order of tabling, and then it is one speaker each per group. This is how it has been explained to me.  For me this is a difficult situation, but I would say – and I take this on my shoulders now – if you all agree on this, if all the speakers that I just mentioned are fine with that, I think we should then proceed as the people concerned suggest. Is everyone fine with that? OK. Hannah Neumann. But then you have to tell me who’s next!

name: Hannah Neumann
text: author. – Madam President, before the summer I spoke to Maria Ressa. She had just lost a made-up case, and I was so worried about the human rights situation in the Philippines.  I said Maria, what can we do as the international community? She said ‘democracy dies in darkness so you should is shed light on the situation’. That is exactly why we are having this debate today and that’s why I’m happy to see you here Ms Urpilainen. But someone is missing, and that’s our new trade commissioner Mr Dombrovskis, because as the European Union we don’t have that many tools to protect human rights and democracy, and maybe our trade policy is the strongest one. But Duterte, the president of the Philippines, who is encouraging his own services to kill tens of thousands of people, still enjoys EU trade privileges the under the GSP Plus scheme that are supposedly linked to improvements in human rights.  The situation is just getting worse, and that’s why I’m so happy that across all political parties in this resolution we call on the Commission to start the procedure to revoke these privileges immediately and – to be frank – by immediately, we mean by Monday.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima
text: Author. Madam President, the human rights situation in the Philippines is of great concern. Extrajudicial executions in the fight against drugs are unacceptable practices in terms of human dignity, but also of international law. We strongly condemn them. Just as we condemn threats, intimidation, rape and violence of all kinds against those in the country who protest against these practices, including human rights defenders and journalists. Freedom of the press is also relative in the country in view of threats, intimidation and violence against journalists. In this context, I would like to mention the name of journalist Maria Ressa. In view of the distress experienced by many people in the Philippines, we express our condemnation of violence against LGBTIQ people; our condemnation of the trafficking of children, of their recruitment for armed conflicts; our condemnation of the rape of women and girls, rapes trivialized by statements made by President Duterte, absolutely unacceptable. The MEPs who will vote for this resolution urge the Government of the Philippines to comply with its obligations under international law and we call on the European Union to use all appropriate means to bring the Philippine government to governance in accordance with human rights.

name: Niels Fuglsang
text: author. – Madam President, last June, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights presented an alarming report on the human rights violations in the Philippines, where the situation is horrendous.  For half a decade, the so-called war on drugs has led to thousands of killings by illegal police actions and death squads. Hundreds of thousands of people have been arrested. In these five years, the European Parliament has written four declarations concerning the state of the human rights in the Philippines, but the situation has not improved whatsoever. On the contrary, since last year, the country has actually withdrawn from the International Criminal Court jurisdiction, and recently there has been a resurgence of extra-judicial killings, assassinations of human rights activists and intimidation and prosecutions of journalists. The most notorious is the former CNN journalist, Maria Ressa, who is now exposed to one hundred years in prison as a result of all the charges against her. The Philippines should adopt and implement the recommendations from the UN report and, without substantial improvement, we as the European Union should suspend the Philippines’ beneficial trade preferences with us.

name: Bernard Guetta
text: Author. Madam President, Hold the line, stand up, in French, is the promise that Mr Duterte's opponents have courageously, noblely, made. Stand up because in the Philippines nearly 9,000 people and probably many more have been killed by power henchmen under the pretext of drug trafficking or use. Stand up because, journalists, intellectuals, academics or lawyers, opponents risk not only arrest, but also murder. Stand up because the prison occupancy rate has just reached 534%. Dictators are usually indignant about the damning reports, but Mr Duterte, no, quite the contrary, he boasts of it, because, to hear it, we must not - especially not - bother with procedures and respect for human rights. He is there, and that is enough since this supreme judge has given himself the right to life and death. History had another Duterte, it was in Rome, his name was Nero. Mr. Duterte, to all of us' shame, is the Nero of modern times.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. – Madam President, in the Philippines, during the alleged war on drugs, more than 27,000 people have been killed and, with the excuse of the fight against terrorism, trade unionists, human rights defenders, activists and journalists such as Zara Alvarez, Maria Ressa and Leila de Lima are attacked, murdered and imprisoned. But apparently, these human rights violations are not sufficient for the right of this Parliament to demand in a resounding and clear manner the immediate suspension of the privileges granted under the system of generalised preferences, a system which should be conditional on the application of international human and labour rights conventions which are clearly not being fulfilled right now in the Philippines.  We demand that military weapons and equipment be discontinued with the Philippines and that trade preferences be immediately suspended until human rights are respected. This has to be done urgently. Already. Let's not wait till tomorrow.

name: Adam Bielan
text: author. – Madam President, in the Philippines, the situation of citizens, human rights defenders and media representatives has been worsening in recent years.  The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights’ report of June 2020 found that the killings related to the government’s anti—drug campaign were ‘widespread and systematic’. At least 8 663 people have been killed, according to government data, and some estimations even triple that number. Meanwhile, human rights defenders, journalists such as Maria Ressa and activists routinely face harassment, intimidation and violence for seeking to expose allegations of extrajudicial killings. Threats, intimidation, violence, harassment, unfair prosecutions or corruption do not go hand-in-hand with a democratically elected government. Today, we call on the Republic of the Philippines to cease immediately all violence and human rights abuses. The fight against illicit drugs must be pursued in full compliance with due process of law.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, extrajudicial executions in the war on drugs and terrorism have multiplied and continue with impunity. The Philippines Human Rights Commission has estimated that nearly 27,000 people have died. Duterte continues to use this war to eliminate, torture, and threaten the actors who hinder him - leaders, peasants, priests, journalists, lawyers - without accountability. The latest UN report highlights the urgent need for further investigations into these violations. The UN Human Rights Council must now set up an independent international mechanism to investigate extraordinary executions and other violations in that country. But in this climate of repression and terror, local communities no longer dare to seek justice for the violations they have suffered, nor to oppose the government. It is time that we support them, that we help them to do this work. And finally, the question we must also ask ourselves is this: why maintain a preferential regime of access to the European market in this context of massive repression of human rights? Today, in the Philippines, there are 18,000 women and children working in unprotected mines, 85,000 children who work, forced, in agriculture. This GSP has no reason to be with the Philippines today.

name: Lars Patrick Berg
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to confine my brief remarks to the specific case of Maria Ressa. As far as I know, Mrs Ressa is currently on bail and is awaiting her verdict. I am also aware that the judge in this case stated that Ms Ressa did not appear to be able to substantiate her allegations and did not provide any evidence to support them.  However, I also have no doubt that contract killings are taking place in the Philippines and that serious violations of human rights are being committed. The detention of Mrs Ressa is, of course, completely exaggerated, and so are the accusations of defamation. However, I think it is up to Mrs Ressa's legal team to provide evidence to support her original story. And then we can talk about the repression or the suspension of freedom of speech and the harassment of the media by the government.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their remarks.  The EU has expressed its concern about various human rights issues in the Philippines on numerous occasions, recently through the EU 27 statement at the Human Rights Council and the February 2020 biennial Generalised Scheme of Preferences report discussed in the European Parliament, as well as directly through the authorities, such as during the first Joint Committee of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in January 2020.  More specifically on Maria Ressa’s case, the EU External Action Service spokesperson issued a statement on 16 June 2020 – so a few months ago – underlining that her conviction raised serious doubts over the respect for freedom of expression, as well as for the rule of law, in the Philippines.  We expect the Philippines, like all countries, to uphold its international human rights obligations and protect and promote fundamental freedoms.  With regard to the monitoring of the Philippines’ commitment under GSP+, the Trade Commissioner – you were referring to that, Ms Neumann – had clearly communicated our concerns to his counterpart in Manila, and the Philippines’ reply will be taken into account in assessing compliance through the chief GSP+ conditionalities during our bilateral dialogue with the Government.  The EU remains convinced that both the Philippines and the EU have most to gain from constructive engagement. During our January Joint Committee, we agreed on the establishment of a Sub—Committee on Good Governance, Rule of Law and Human Rights. This sub—committee, expected to meet regularly, will be an important forum for directly addressing all human rights issues. The External Action Service has proposed to hold a first meeting already this autumn – by the end of this year – even under a virtual format. So the European Commission and the External Action Service will continue raising these matters with the Philippine Government in a clear and constructive way.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on Dr Denis Mukwege's case in the Democratic Republic of Congo (2020/2783(RSP)*. ------ * See Minutes.

name: Maria Arena
text: Author. Madam President, Denis Mukwege, a gynaecologist and human rights activist, is devoting his life to combating sexual violence against women in eastern DRC, her country and her region. For more than 20 years, Denis Mukwege and his teams have faced the worst atrocities against women, girls and even babies: raped, genitals ransacked by criminals belonging to armed groups, who use such violence as a weapon of war and mass destruction. More than 55,000 women, girls and children have been treated in Panzi Hospital since its inception, and unfortunately this is not about to stop. The recent attacks in Ituri, described as crimes against humanity by Ms. Bachelet, and the tensions in the Kivus remain very worrying. In this context, Denis Mukwege, as always, took clear positions, calling for the fight against impunity not to remain in the report, referring to the Mapping report, but for everyone to take responsibility. He called on the DRC to guarantee the protection of the population and to ensure the demilitarization of mining sites. It calls on the international community to support the judicial process in the DRC with the establishment of joint tribunals. It also calls on the international community to prosecute the perpetrators of crimes classified as crimes against humanity in the Mapping report for the period 1993-2003, and to support the creation of an ad hoc tribunal, because, as everyone knows, the International Criminal Court has no jurisdiction over the matter.  His positions have again earned him threats that must be taken seriously, because since the creation of his first hospital, which was destroyed in 1996, he was threatened in 2012 and is again under threats today. We must protect it, yes, but we must also ensure that it can no longer last in the DRC. That is how Mr. Mukwege will be most protected, that is how he can continue to work as a human rights activist.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: Author. Madam President, the attacks and intimidations targeting Nobel Peace Prize laureate Denis Mukwege since 2012 and until July 2020 are a borderline case of violence targeting medical personnel in the conflict-ravaged eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. This situation underlines the scope of the work of the man who, since 1999, has rescued some 50,000 victims of sexual violence, sometimes severely mutilated, in his hospital in Panzi, aptly denouncing these abuses as a real tactic of terror. Let us not cast anathema to the Democratic Republic of Congo, which has demonstrated some determination against these crimes, although, from compensation for victims to supporting children from rape, much remains to be done. For our part, our UN and European resolutions will indeed have no effect until the players in the tantalum trade, the underlying cause of the conflict, take their responsibilities. Similarly, any international assistance in the face of health crises in Africa will come to the challenge of the safety of medical practitioners, whose case of Denis Mukwege is now the tragic emblem, alas.

name: Marisa Matias
text: author. – Madam President, I ask you not to count this as an intervention. I think it is more correct if, after the colleague who negotiated the resolution, we then have all the authors according to the d’Hondt method. So I’m more than happy to speak last, so give the floor to the colleagues in the correct order as usual. They know who they are. I’ll be speaking last.
