name: President. –
text: I am really sorry for the confusion; the lists are still a little bit incorrect. So the next speaker is then Mr Vincze from the EPP.

name: Loránt Vincze
text: author. – Madam President, my appreciation to the colleague for agreeing to use speaking time on the weight of the groups. It takes extreme bravery to be an outspoken defender of human rights in a state crippled by decades of corruption and armed conflict and in which rebel militia groups continue to abduct, rape and murder civilians with impunity. Dr Denis Mukwege, renowned gynaecologist, pastor, Nobel and Sakharov prize laureate from the Democratic Republic of Congo, has dedicated most of his life to end the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war and armed conflict. Nearly 55 000 survivors have been treated in Panzi hospital, which he established in 1999. His courage, dedication and strength in denouncing wartime sexual violence made him the international symbol of this struggle. Now his life, and those of his co—workers and members of his family, are newly and repeatedly under threat. It is our moral obligation that we defend them with all the means at our disposal. While raising our voice for Dr Mukwege, we praise all human rights defenders in the Democratic Republic of Congo who still carry out their work in spite of the challenges they are faced with. The EPP Group welcomes the resolution that urges the government of the DRC to undertake immediately a comprehensive investigation into the threats he and other human rights defenders have received. I also welcome that the document calls upon the Congolese Government and judiciary to prosecute human rights abuses carried out against women in that country. We fully echo Dr Mukwege’s call for peace and justice, the defence of human rights, the need for accountability and the implementation of the UN human rights report mapping abuses.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: Author. Madam President, Dr. Mukwege is a hero. A hero for the Congolese women he repairs and to whom he restores the desire to live and dignity. A surrogate father - basically - for all victims of sexual crimes. Denis Mukwege is also a hero to human rights activists around the world, where his courage commands admiration. He is still the victim of death threats today, but Denis Mukwege does not hide, our Sakharov Prize is not silent, either, he tells the truth and assumes the risks, which are immense, we know. So our obligation today is to stop the incantation. First, he and his relatives must be protected and then his demand for justice for the victims of the conflicts ravaging the east of the country. Certainly, the Monusco is back, we can say that Panzi remains a refuge, but for how long? As we know, the protection of the United Nations is temporary. Now the work of memory remains, justice remains. A peaceful Congo and a Congo reconciled with its history, a Congo that puts an end to the impunity of the executioners, it is this Congo, that of Dr. Mukwege, that Europe must accompany - beyond words, beyond incantation - in deeds, and this is what our text proposes.

name: Salima Yenbou
text: Author. Madam President, today the European Parliament is expressing its solidarity and support for Dr Mukwege, the man who repairs women, because he is unfortunately the victim of death threats. We call on the Congolese government to continue and intensify its fight against all human rights violations and, in the wake of the UN Mapping report, to put in place judicial means to try past and present crimes, but also to respect sexual and reproductive rights, including the legalization of abortion in cases of rape. But let us not forget that behind all this is the problem of mineral exploitation, which leads to corruption and violence. The Amish have no responsibility for these crimes. The same cannot be said of us, who use our smartphone every day, which we will probably have to change with the upcoming 5G. This resolution honours not only Dr. Mukwege and human rights defenders in the DRC, but also the entire Sakharov Prize-winning community, to whom we say thank you. The European Parliament will continue to support your struggles.

name: Marisa Matias
text: Author. – Madam President, Denis Mukwege has devoted most of his life to trying to end the use of sexual violence against women as a weapon of war.  Denis Mukwege treated more than 55,000 surviving victims at Panzi Hospital. His life has always been threatened, but in recent months these threats have become very strong. Sexual violence against women in the context of war cannot go unpunished and, therefore, we welcome the recent decision that was taken on 3 September, an important court decision not to keep this crime unpunished. But in addition to what conflicts within the territory are, there is still violence that is multiplied by the presence of foreign groups that, in the east of the country, exploit minerals. In this regard, we call on the international community to support human rights defenders in Congo, not to let go of the crimes committed and to refuse to trade with companies that hold natural resources and promote violence in the country.

name: Assita Kanko
text: author. – Madam President, years ago I was honoured to interview Dr Mukwege for a book I wrote on women’s rights. He inspired me with his simple belief that we all have a duty to do the right thing. He is not a man who thinks women’s rights is an issue for women. He just jumps in and fights. He said, ‘I became a feminist because, in the face of the atrocity I witnessed, I had a choice: to go away or to act. I couldn’t just leave’. The EU must do all it can to protect the points of light that shine through darkness. For the many thousands of victims of sexual violence in the Congo, Dr Mukwege is that light. We must call for a deep and impartial investigation into the threats made against him, and the EU must urge the Congolese authorities to adopt the draft law which protects human rights defenders and installs transitional justice. By defending Dr Mukwege’s life, we also defend the lives and dignity of those that every day rely upon his bravery. We must do all we can to help him continue to fight for the change he has spent a lifetime trying to achieve: the delivery of justice, truth and the empowerment of women.

name: Krzysztof Hetman
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today we are considering the case of Dr. Denis Mukwege, nobel peace prize winner and long-time social activist, who was also awarded the Sakharov Prize. The hospital, of which Dr. Mukwege is the director, is the largest center for helping victims of rape and sexual violence in the country, and the doctor himself openly opposes sexual violence and demands justice for its victims.  Dr. Mukwege fiercely defends the victims of violence, but now it's time to defend him too. It is because of his work that Dr. Mukwege, but also his family and colleagues, receive death threats. Unfortunately, an attempt was made once to assassinate Dr. Mukwege, in which one of his bodyguards was killed. We cannot therefore doubt that the threat is as real as possible. I therefore believe that the European Parliament cannot therefore be indifferent to this threat. We must demand action to protect Dr Mukwege, but we must also call on the Government of the Democratic Republic of congo to launch a thorough investigation in order to establish the source of the threats that Dr Mukwege receives, his loved ones and hospital staff.  Today's debate is certainly an opportunity to draw attention to the problems that Dr Mukwege has been dealing with for years. The European Union naturally condemns sexual violence, but our role cannot be limited to it. Activists in the Democratic Republic of Congo who are active against violence, including sexual violence, and who support its victims should be clearly supported and demanded decisive action by the government in this regard.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, in congo, sexual abuse is used as weapons of war and the doctor who clinically denounces and treats these crimes is under threat of death. This doctor is Denis Mukwege, winner of the Sakharov Prize and the Nobel Peace Prize. The European Union, the United Nations, the African Union and the states of law must all be at their side in the fight against the serious violations of human rights and impunity with which the most basic pillars of society are run over. The recent denunciation of another massacre in Kivu and the call for armed groups responsible for continued crimes of sexual violence to be brought to justice by the armed groups responsible for the continued crimes of sexual violence have posed a real threat to their physical integrity, which has demanded the replacement of protection by UN forces to Panzi Hospital, which was interrupted in May this year because of the pandemic. We must ensure the functioning of judicial bodies and the European Union must remain vigilant and proactive and sanction all perpetrators of violence and human rights violators. I reiterate my solidarity with Dr Denis Mukwege and his clinical staff for the extraordinary work of combating sexual violence as a terrorist strategy and action.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am outraged, shocked and concerned that we need to discuss the safety of Dr Denis Mukwege. This shows how terror and impunity have reached an unprecedented level on a human scale in this region.  This man, who must no longer be presented - the Sakharov Prize, the Nobel Peace Prize, and above all a hero for an entire people - is the voice of raped women, the wall against suffering, terror and executions. Colleagues, it is our duty to strengthen this bulwark which defends our fundamental values in his country. Amani Kwenu. Peace for you. Vrede voor u.

name: Christine Anderson
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Doctor Mukwege deserves my utmost respect for his tireless fight against this bestial sexual violence against women and girls and their devastating consequences. I strongly condemn the cowardly attempts at intimidation and death threats against him, his family and associates.  But instead of repeating our horror, our dismay, when are we finally acting? Since the ridiculous election in 2018, Congo has slipped further and further into anarchy. Rapes, attacks on women by militias take place every day, five million refugees in tent camps – and the perpetrators enjoy impunity. Either because they are covered by high-ranking military figures, or because they have nothing to fear from the jurisdiction, which is largely rife with corruption.  But, and this is the real scandal, while the systematic sexual violence against women, the right-wing shootings continue to increase, the Congolese Government is still supported by the EU. This year alone, with EUR 40 million in humanitarian aid. It is imperative that we, as the EU, critically examine our attitude and relationship with Congo so that people like Doctor Mukwege no longer have to risk their lives to protect women from this bestial violence.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Dr. Denis Mukwege, nobel peace prize winner, Sakharov Prize, an extremely strong, courageous, heroic doctor who fights with great determination, commitment and effectiveness against sexual violence and the exploitation of women in armed conflicts. It publicized information about rape. He speaks publicly about the impunity of the authorities. Now he needs our strong support. So it is our duty now to ensure its safety, which is why we call on the UN and the Congolese Government to ensure the safety of the doctor, his family, patients, hospital staff. We should support the victims of sexual violence in Congo, as well as the activists who are helping them.

name: Isabel Wiseler-Lima (PPE).
text: Madam President, Dr Denis Mukwege is an admirable person, having devoted most of his life to combating sexual violence as a weapon of war. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2018 after receiving the Sakharov Prize in 2014. This 2014 choice expresses better than we can today our admiration for Dr Mukwege, but this choice also implies for us, even today, a special responsibility as an MEP. We owe it to him so that he can continue to defend human rights safely. The present threats to his fundamental right to life are due to his tireless struggle, and in particular to his calls to end the impunity enjoyed by those who commit sexual crimes and massacres in several provinces of the Democratic Republic of Congo. We therefore strongly appeal to the Congolese authorities to ensure the safety of Dr. Mukwege and to ensure that the perpetrators of the threats are prevented from harming and are brought to justice. But we also call on the international community to step up its efforts to eliminate the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war, protect victims, end impunity for perpetrators and ensure access to justice and reparation for victims.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me start with a quotation:‘Rape is not just a physical violent act perpetrated against one victim. It’s an assault on humanity’. These are the words of Denis Mukwege.  Dr Mukwege has dedicated his life to the treatment of women who have become victims of rape and horrendous sexual violence. He has given new hope to tens of thousands of women, supporting them on the way back through medical treatment and psychological counsel, giving them the chance to get back on their own two feet by providing them with an education and job training. He needs our support to ensure his safety and that of his family and staff.  Women are amongst the most vulnerable in conflicts across the globe. Using sexual violence as a weapon in a war is a terrible crime. Denis Mukwege is one of the big heroes of our time. He needs our support and he deserves it.

name: Samira Rafaela (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I welcome Nobel Peace Prize winner Dr Mukwege’s call for protection and the resolution in support for this. We know that conflict has horrible consequences for the countries concerned, for the many women victimised. As Dr Mukwege correctly said, we need to recognise that sexual violence in conflict is not just a problem in his country. Therefore, it is important that people like Dr Mukwege can continue their important work, work that not only helps the victims but also advocates for women’s rights.  Dr Mukwege and his Panzi Hospital are an example of how activists who do the groundwork need and deserve our protection. A pandemic cannot be an excuse to look away. Our support, especially during a crisis, is desperately needed. I call on our institutions, our Parliament and the international community to ensure that people like Dr Mukwege are free and safe to continue their work.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his "No rest that is not everyone's, no stillness until everything is completed" said former UN Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjöld. These are words that we must take into account. There is a heavy responsibility on us to take the fight to uphold human rights and freedoms and to support all the forces fighting for them around the world. Dr Denis Mukwege is a shining example of what courage, tenacity and bearing hope can do for human rights. However, as is so often the case for those who stand up for equality and human rights, he, his colleagues and his family have been constantly subjected to hatred and attempted murder because of the important work he does. It is welcome that Dr Mukwege is once again being protected by the UN, albeit temporarily. However, it is not acceptable that this should only happen under pressure. What is the signal we are sending to all human rights defenders? That they will stand alone when the danger comes? No, that's enough! We need a Europe that is committed globally to women's rights in a true feminist foreign policy spirit and, at the same time, continues to actively talk to the UN to safeguard the situation of human rights defenders who are daily risking their lives for the freedom of others.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am grateful to the Members of the European Parliament for raising this matter, and for giving me the opportunity to address it here. The European Union greatly admires the courage and the tireless work of Dr Denis Mukwege. His strong commitment to peace, justice and human rights in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has unfortunately exposed him to death threats. Despite that, he continues to devote his life to defending and restoring the dignity of countless women, the victims of brutal acts of violence, and we must continue to support his work. We have publicly condemned the most recent threats made against him and we are pleased to note that the UN has now decided to redeploy a unit for the safety of Dr Mukwege and the staff and patients of the Panzi Hospital. We remain extremely worried about almost daily attacks on the population in the east of the DRC. This cannot become a forgotten crisis 10 years after the UN Mapping Exercise Report. We are calling upon the DRC, supported by its international partners, in particular in the region and the United Nations Organisation Stabilisation Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO), to put an end to the violence and the impunity. The Congolese authorities should adopt and implement reforms to establish effective security institutions and an independent justice sector. Those responsible should be brought before justice so that the rights and dignity of the victims can finally be recognised. The EU is taking concrete action in this direction through support programmes for justice, the strengthening of the mechanism for prosecuting and supporting victims, including survivors of sexual and gender-based violence, and is continuing its direct support to Dr Mukwege’s Panzi Hospital, which so far amounts to EUR 19 million. We will never, never abandon the women and girls who had to go through the unspeakable pain of sexual violence, and stand ready to contribute to the support they need to rebuild their lives.

text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on the humanitarian situation in Mozambique (2020/2784(RSP)*. ------ * See Minutes.

name: Paulo Rangel
text: Author. – Madam President, we cannot leave Mozambique, we cannot leave Mozambique and mozambicans by the wayside. There is now a terrible humanitarian drama in northern Mozambique, in cabo delgado province, there are already more than 1,500 dead, there are hundreds of thousands displaced, there is terrorism in the villages and towns of Mozambique. Many of the young women have been kidnapped or sexually enslaved, many of the young men have been fortly recruited to militias and temporary armies. It is an offensive clearly inspired by Islamic jihadists, extremism, with proven links to Daesh. This humanitarian drama, which is living in one of the poorest countries in the world, which already had rates of development of the terrible, which has been plagued by climate change, cyclones caused by very serious climate change, this is a political and religious problem that adds to this tragic situation. And it's serious, very serious, and so I insist.  The forgetfulness to which the international community and the European Union, in particular, voted for the situation in Mozambique. The pandemic doesn't excuse everything. It cannot be a veil that covers what is happening in northern Mozambique. No one speaks of Mozambique, not in the nearest countries, such as Portugal, or like Italy, which have special responsibilities towards Mozambique, nor these! This is a topical issue. This is not just a problem for Mozambicans who are suffering and need humanitarian aid. It is also a regional problem because islamic jihadism is spreading throughout the countries around it, which has already come from the Sahel, which came from the Horn of Africa, there are several outbreaks across Africa that we are not paying attention to and, therefore, it is essential to support the European Union, the involvement of the African Union, the involvement of the South African Development Community , southern Africa.  We have to involve all these partners to save these people who are in despair and who, in addition to despair, are totally forgotten and abandoned by the international community. The role of the Catholic Church and, in particular, the Bishop of Pemba, Luíz Lisboa, who has been the only international voice to echo what christian populations and Muslim populations who have always lived peacefully and have never had any radicalism in this region are suffering.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: Author. – Madam President, endemic poverty, economic greed, institutional fragility, natural disasters and terrorism under the cover of religious intolerance have created a context of humanitarian crisis in cabo delgado province. The known numbers of attacks and civilian casualties and the images circulating about the atrocities committed are shocking. The joint resolution we are debating explicitly, but objectively, the reasons why we have to act quickly. Commissioner, we cannot take refuge in the excuse of complexity, nor of the pandemic, for abandoning the people of Cabo Delgado. We have to act in a united way on the roots of the problem, but we must respond immediately to the humanitarian urgency we face.  The multilateral dialogue between the European Union and the Government of Mozambique, as well as with regional economic political organisations, needs to be deepened, also functioning as a catalyst to encourage dialogue between national authorities and civil society. And yes, Mr Rangel, the Member States also have a role to play and, fortunately, Portugal, through its Minister for Foreign Affairs, has played that role. May it serve as an example and also serve as a motivator for the work that needs to be continued.

name: Jan-Christoph Oetjen
text: author. – Madam President, the humanitarian situation in Mozambique is dire. The people of Mozambique are faced with one crisis after another, yet their plight is often neglected and ignored around the world. Since 2017, Mozambique has been in a constant state of insecurity and has suffered from terrorist attacks by the so—called al—Shabaab and one climate—related natural disaster after the other. The Mozambique authorities need the assistance of the international community to combat this danger. But military insurgencies are no excuse for human rights violations reprisals, and the government of Mozambique has the responsibility to protect its citizens, not make them fear for their lives. We therefore call on Mozambique to investigate without delay the alleged accusations of human rights abuses against their security forces and to respect the fundamentals of international law. We call on them to immediately cease the mauling of freedom of speech and to defend the universal value of freedom of speech. We also call on the international community to work closely with the local authorities to address the humanitarian crisis which follows these natural disasters and is only worsened by COVID—19.

name: Katrin Langensiepen
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We in the European Parliament have the opportunity, with our resolutions, to look where it does not fall first when it comes to violations of fundamental human rights. That is currently the case in Mozambique. Mozambique, a country ravaged by climate disasters, unrest, military violence and a lack of democracy. We are not concerned about arrogance, we are really worried about the people on the ground. When journalists and human rights activists are arbitrarily restricted in their freedoms and subjected to violence, we call for this and demand that universal standards be respected. If they disappear, when they report on corruption, human rights violations and terrorism in the province of Cabo Delgado, we name it and we demand clarification. The EU-Africa Strategy and the forthcoming EU-AU Summit offer the opportunity to discuss issues of security, sustainable development and concrete scenarios of international cooperation and social progress as partners on an equal footing. Let us see the African continent, Mozambique, not as a region in need of help, but as a partner. Let us seize the opportunity!

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, condolences to the families of the victims. These are hundreds of people, more than a thousand people. Also, condolences to those who had to leave their homes as a result of this Islamic insurgency. It is good that we are talking about this today, it is an expression of solidarity with these people. I also wanted to make it very clear – and this is where my political group's amendment went – that not only poverty and lack of prospects are a source of terrorism, but it is also often an ideology. These are strictly ideological reasons, because sometimes wealthy people also resort to terrorism. It is worth seeing this in a broader context and it is good that today we express solidarity with the people of Mozambique, in Cabo Delgado.

name: Marisa Matias
text: Author. – Madam President, the situation in Mozambique has worsened greatly in recent years and the discovery of huge gas reserves, the largest areas in the world, has only aggravated the situation and increased levels of corruption. Currently, with the pandemic and as a result of natural disasters, there are 7.9 million people in need of assistance. We have witnessed a huge humanitarian tragedy that we need to respond to.  More than 1,500 people have died in Cabo Delgado and the country's wealth of natural resources has led multinationals to compete, such as vultures, to gain access to the region. This is the example of French Total, which continues with exploration plans as if nothing was happening, as if there were nothing.  What we need in this situation is, in fact, to denounce what is going on and end the silence. Condemning terrorist attacks and jihadism is fundamental, but it is not enough. It is necessary to denounce and stop the exploitation of natural resources. Environmental rights must be taken into account and we need to link all this with the economic and social context. Otherwise, we cover the sun with the sieve, but we do not really help the people in Mozambique.

name: Lars Patrick Berg
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The reasons for the humanitarian disaster in Mozambique are complex, but I would like to point out that the main reason for this disaster is the race to exploit the oil and gas fields, especially offshore fields, which are among the largest gas resources in Africa.  But the problems are best illustrated by the case of André Hanekom, a South African citizen and owner of a small marina, which was seen as a strategic base for supplying the offshore industry. His reluctance to sell his property led to his kidnapping by Mozambican security forces, false accusations of dealing with Islamists, and eventually his death in police custody. The actions of so-called PMC, private military companies, murders, the rise of Islamism and many other unpleasant things are due to rampant corruption. All this is widespread in today's Mozambique, and yet at the heart of this anarchy are many foreign oil companies, including some from Europe, that tolerate these murders in the name of security. The multinationals must recognise the responsibility they have to stop the killing in Mozambique.

name: Željana Zovko
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, in Mozambique since 2010, Cabo Delgado has witnessed the discovery of substantial gas reserves off its coasts. This area is now home to Africa’s largest liquefied natural gas, attracting enormous investment for eventual extraction. Since 2017, this northern province has been rocketed by deadly attacks perpetrated by armed groups whose operations are becoming increasingly sophisticated. Even before the discovery of the gas reserves and the attacks, Cabo Delgado was already nursing discontentment due to the high level of poverty and marginalisation by the central government. The Bishop of Pemba has received death threats for being outspoken on behalf of the poor in Cabo Delgado. He has called on the government to do more to protect the people against Jihadist attacks linked to ISIS. With this resolution we also urge the government of Mozambique to take effective and decisive action against the insurgencies of international terrorist groups.  Dear colleagues, the government of Mozambique has a big responsibility, but unfortunately lacks the means. A coordinated response from the region and international efforts are urgently needed. This week we adopted the new and an effective European approach on fighting terrorism in the Sahel and the Horn of Africa. Building on these experiences we can offer our assistance to the people of Mozambique.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, cyclones, plural; cholera, malaria, COVID-19, plural; violence, in the plural: terrorist violence, in the north, political violence, at the centre, institutional violence, in elections — and I regret that there is no greater reference to this issue; lack of food distribution; accusations of torture of the security forces; political corruption in all areas; attacked journalists and burned-down media; Western companies making the prey of natural resources and a drug trafficking uncontrollable. It is like an epitome, as a summary of all the ills of Africa, but concentrated in time and space. Mozambique has at some point been a great hope for the European Union, and the European Union made a great financial and political investment in Mozambique, and we are as we are. That means we have to completely change our perspective. What has been done so far is not enough.  Changes must be demanded, and the existence of violence cannot be an excuse to stop demanding the reforms that that country needs. Because if we do not make reforms at the institutional level, the situation of violence, hunger or disrespect for human rights will not be manageable. TheRefore, the European Union needs to change its approach with Mozambique. Not just aid: demand for reforms.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, in 2005, under the aegis of the United Nations, the Heads of State and Government agreed on the principle of the responsibility to protect. The analysis behind this statement was finalized in the Responsibility to Protect document that everyone knows. The main lessons of this declaration are that there is no security without development and that there is no development without security. The answer cannot be just humanitarian. It is certainly humanitarian, but we also need to work on the longer term. To solve this long-term crisis, a strong state must be able to carry out its regal functions. It is in this context that I call on the Commission to clarify perhaps already their view of the programming reserved for Mozambique in the next seven years. The Instrument of Neighbourhood, Development Cooperation and International Cooperation (IVCDCI) which we adopted at first reading has a wide range of instruments that can help the creation of this strong state and the strengthening of its governance. I agree with everything that has been said about the suffering in the country, I also express my compassion, but we also have to work on the long term.

name: Isabel Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, and I take the words of my colleague Mr Goerens to say that, in fact, there is no security without development and there is no development without security. Time is of the essence and against us to respond to those who are now refugees in the bush, without water, without food, without medical care, of responding to the more than 7 million people who urgently need help and who are fighting in an impoverished country and a country that has experienced several disasters over the past few times.  The European Union is therefore obliged to respond, but a structured response, as a first step, a humanitarian response to what are the most pressing needs of the population, and in a second instance that it must go in parallel, in a project developed together with other local institutions, regional organisations, neighbouring governments in order to have a development and peace programme for the region and what is happening in Mozambique does not only affect mozambique and has a vast potential to affect neighbouring countries. But I cannot speak of Mozambique without talking about the case of Américo Sebastião, a European citizen of Portuguese nationality, who disappeared for 4 years in the province of Sofala and I want here to ask all european authorities, in dialogue with the Mozambican authorities, to raise this case and ask for an explanation for this case. There is a family and there is a set of friends who are still waiting today for an explanation for what happened to Américo Sebastião.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, last year when cyclones Idai and Kenneth struck, the EU used all available instruments to respond to those tragedies. Today, northern Mozambique faces another threat: an outbreak of armed violence with a dangerous regional dimension. I would first like to reiterate our solidarity with the people of Mozambique. We have strong political and developmental relations with Mozambique and we are ready to discuss options for assistance. I am also glad to inform you that the government and the EU have opened a policy dialogue, with a focus on humanitarian development and security issues in Cabo Delgado. In the April Council conclusions, the EU emphasised that, regardless of the urgency, any response to the violence in the north must ensure full respect for human rights. The recent Amnesty report is extremely shocking. All its allegations, including those concerning members of the Mozambique armed defence forces and the police, must be investigated transparently and effectively, with full respect for the legal rights of both the victims and the accused. The EU advocates an integrated and coordinated approach to development, promoting democracy, human rights and the rule of law. This encompasses also freedom of the media and civil society, and I recall here the memory of the activist and electoral observer, Anastácio Matavele. Let me also underline our commitment to following African processes, working with the African Union Peace and Security Architecture and especially SADC. I think this is the way to ensure the regional drivers and impacts of this crisis are properly addressed.

name: Dominique Bilde (ID)
text: In writing. Words are lacking to condemn the abominable attack on a woman isolated by armed men - an atrocity about which the outcome of the investigation should be expected.  But let's not hide the harshness of Mozambique's fight against the Islamic State movement, Al-Shabaab, which has been setting Cabo Delgado on fire since 2017. This is a struggle that this country is fighting on its own, since the Southern African Development Community has so far been conspicuous by its absence.  At the end of the day, the usual lot of carnage, especially against Christians who have seen their buildings reduced to ashes in recent times and some who among their faithful refused to abjure their faith, cowardly murdered. In this regard, this dramatic situation is in line with similar tragedies in Nigeria or Burkina Faso.  Thus, even if complex geopolitical debates remain relevant, we must not, by a false politically correct modesty, dodge the denunciation of a quasi-genocide, which from sub-Saharan Africa to the Middle East, decimates Christians in general silence.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We will continue with today's second vote. We will vote on the motions as indicated on the agenda. Voting is possible from 13:00 to 14:15. The voting method shall be the same as that used in the previous vote. All polls are by name. I'm opening the second ballot, you have until 2:15 p.m. The results of the second vote will be announced at 4:30 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 2.15 p.m.)
